info.content:
In the morning Daddy and Ben went to their favourite London carpark, Gunnersbury Park. From there they started a 18 mile tour of West London's entertainment centres. Ben was on a navigation as well as biking on the London roads. Only once did he swerve right in front of Daddy almost causing a collision in the road! The boys took in Brentford FC, Fulham FC, Chelsea FC, Earls Court, Olympia, Shepherds Bush Empire and QPR. Ben loved it and wants to do some more London landmark based bike rides.

London Bike Tour

Route

In the evening we had the Elders over for a traditional New Years Eve party..... with the usual party games. Boys v Girls. Toby, Lily and Joey all stayed over which was nice.

News Years Girls

title.value: West London Football Ground tour, New Years with Elders

info.content:
This year there were 20 of us attending the Yvonne Arnaud theatre in Guildford. The theatre was one of the best. Great view, big stage and circular. A theatre has to be circular to be proper!

Cinderella

We all enjoyed the performance.

In the morning Daddy went to Langley to do the Black Park parkrun. There were over 800 runners on a relatively narrow pathway. It took a kilometer to get over the traffic. The last 4km were all sub 5 minutes which is the goal these days.

Later in the afternoon we had a visit from the Sanders crew. We've not met up since last Easter. We swapped presents. The Sanders got us a lovely game called Get A Grip - we decided to play it. You wrap a glove around your hands which restricts your thumb. Then there were a series of rapidough, titles and physical challenges. It was good fun to play. Ma Ma and Pop Pop popped in for a cuppa too.

Jessica's long term friend Imogen came for a sleepover. The girls played with all the children in and out of the conservatory. Being locked in! They played Minecraft on the PS4 too.

Playing Get A Grip

title.value: Black Park parkrun, Sanders Over, Imogen Sleepover

info.content:
Us three children had over £100 each given over Christmas and so we felt the need to spend.... and spend big in London. Katie was brave enough to travel the tube from Acton Town to Leicester Square.

At Leicester square we saw the big cinemas, where our favourite, Capital Radio was produced and went into M and Ms World. Massive it was.

Capital Radio, Leicester Square

M and M's World

We then headed via China town and Soho up to Oxford Street where we did a lot of shopping. Ben came back with some new Nike Huarache's and a t-shirt. Jessica came back with a Lush Bath Bomb and an Umbrella. Katie bought some shorts and a big, white jacket.

Entering China Town

Daddy of course found somewhere free to park but got scared the Gunnersbury park gates would shut. So after getting off the bus at Acton Green, he ran 2.5km to get the car and collect us. A long day out deserved a fish and chip supper.

In the late afternoon we headed over to the Elders for the usual fun and games with the Barnett family. There were lots of games contributions mainly from Ma Ma and Eva this year.

Boxing Day Family Games

Ben stayed at the Elders, whilst Lily came over to us.

title.value: Boxing Day, Ben and Lily sleepover swap

info.content:
It was a 6am for us. We clambered into Ben's bedroom to see what Father Christmas had left behind. There were 17 presents. Katie's main presents were here pink watch and a Calvin Klein handbag. Ben got a Man Utd top and a boxing punch bag and gloves. Jessica got a manikin and an IPhone 6. We then when into Mummy and Daddy's room to watch them open presents from each other. Mummy got a coat, dress and a jumper. Daddy got a jumper, a t-shirt and a lot of food stuff.

6am start for the opening of FC's presents

We then headed downstairs to open presents from friends.... which was nice.

We got to the Fars for 9:30am for some breakfast and our traditional game of Coppit. Daddy won!

Christmas Breakfast

we returned home for 30 mins whilst Mummy made up some of the Children's Christmas dinner. Auntie Ellie was doing the other half. It was nice and a bit different this year as it was the first time not spent in Istead Rise. The adults also ate, Daddy of course doing his impression of Henry VIII with his massive turkey leg.

Children's Christmas Meal

The post lunch walk was only attended by half the crew. It was a nice walk around Caesars Camp with Lenny.

Route

Grandma joined us this year for the festivities which was nice to see. She sat on the sofa soaking in everyone elses enjoyment. She did very well to keep with it all the way till 9pm.

Philip and Emma also came to see us Children open our presents.

Present opening at the Westons

The adults were next opening their presents. After we had a game of Articulate we collapsed and watched a bit of Michael McIntyre before heading home.

Daddy worked in the morning while the rest of us got on with doing bits and pieces around the house. Jessica made a gingerbread house.

At about 3:30pm we got to the Fars and started straight away with a Treasure Hunt around the Tomlinscote estate devised by Farfar. It was a little easier than last year and Farfar used WhatsApp. A first? Despite that it was felt better if the clues were written on paper on the course. Tough crowd. Each of us won £5 each.

Auntie Susan and Graham arrived and we started eating a little after 5:15pm, of course a traditional Danish affair.... except that is us kiddies. We had the usual butchers sausages!

Danish Christmas Meal

After Daddy won the Risalamande challenge, we played the dice game had a boys vs girls quiz and then on to the main event that is the present opening.

Opening presents at the Fars

In the morning Mummy went to church and watched a nativity play.

After lunch we ventured out into the mild, Berkshire air to complete walk 104, Thatcham Lakes. It was nice. Not much resistance from the troops. Only Ben complaining about the amount of time it would take to get there and back. Daddy had lovely chats with Katie and Ben. Jessica is just a fruit loop.

Thatham Lakes walk

Don't mess with this lot

Route

After returning home we had a family game of Risk. Ben won!

In the evening Daddy went for a run and then watched Watership Down with Mummy. They both almost cried. Mummy not feeling too well at the moment with a sore throat. We are all very excited for tomorrow.

Daddy went off to do Brooklands parkrun this morning and ran his fastest since May 2016, 24:06 minutes. So he was well happy and celebrated with a cuppa down the canal cafe.

Meanwhile, Farmor had both Katie and Jessica over for Christmas cooking. They cooked giffler, vaniljekranse and as Katie calls them, brown cakes and a bakewell tart! Lovely. Jessica also managed to finish sewing her "I Love You" cushion for Mummy.

In the mid afternoon they were picked up by Ma Ma and taken over to Farnborough cinema where they met with Lily to watch the latest carnation of Mary Poppins.

Mummy, Daddy and Ben went over to Mercedes Benz World over in Brooklands (again Daddy!). A place we've surprisingly not been before. There were three floors of cars and history..... as well as a few interactive things. One was a remote control car game. 10 lined up on the grid. Daddy came 4th and Ben 2nd.... although Daddy did get 2nd fastest lap!

Daddy and Ben went on a 4x4 experience where a driver took the pair around a steep gradient off road course. Ben was on the brakes for a 60% decline..... which ended in them sliding down the hill! Ben loved it. They also saw a car race display. It was a really nice chilled afternoon.

Mercedes Benz World

Mummy and Daddy in front of their car

The World Championship winning F1 car

In the evening we all watched Jingle All The Way!

title.value: Mercedes Benz World, Farmor Cooking, Ma Ma Mary Poppins

info.content:
Daddy was let out at 3pm, whilst us three for relieved from school yesterday. Katie had spent most of today doing her Maths homework. It took her ages, but at least she has done it now.

Each year we have a family meal out. This time around we headed to Frankie and Benny's in Aldershot. We all had a go on the kids game sheet! We had a lovely meal.

Frankie and Benny's Christmas Meal out

Mummy and Daddy went out to the Highlight Christmas Meal at the Giggling Squid in Farnham. Same place as last year. We sat opposite Anthony and his wife, Rachel which was very nice. The food was too spicy for Daddy. They had a good time. KBJ were left to themselves.

Daddy and Mummy pre going out

In the afternoon Farmor and Susan took Jessica to a pottery shop where you could make pottery pieces and collect them a week or so later.

Jessica and Farmor pottering

The Potters

title.value: Jessica Pottery making with Farmor and Susan

info.content:
The football was very touch and go this morning. The ref delayed the start and eventually we asked the parents if they accepted a few icey patches on the pitch. We had spent half an hour travelling and almost an hour waiting around, so the resounding response was yes - crack on. Just three weeks previous the two sides met in Mytchett and the scoreline was 2-2. Today was a different story, 8 - 0 to Mytchett. Ben even scored an overhead bicycle kick. Not that I want to take anything away from Ben, it was just a yard out in a goalmouth melee and he hooked the ball over his head as he was falling. Still it was a second goal within a month. Daddy was well pleased, especially as Ben, Abe, Kevon and Ben H all scored! Joey wasn't too gutted at the result. After stopping for a cup of tea with the Elders, they returned home with Joey.

Meanwhile Mummy went with Ma Ma to Cedar Lodge and Holly Lodge to sing with the church to the old people.

In the early afternoon Katie was dropped into Camberley with a few friends. It was kind of a date with Dan who bought her cinema ticket. She watched Spiderman into the Spider-verse. She had a nice time and we gave Dan a lift back home. Katie was all excited and confused. Nothing will come of Dan we suspect.

In the evening we had the traditional Gay's Christmas Party which we hosted. This year we invited just the Elders, Maisey's and West's - no Julie. Mummy made most of the games up which included of course; spoons, titles, give us a clue, a bush tucker trial of a sprout smoothie, the electrocution game and Linkee. Daddy roasted a pork on the BBQ and boiled a gammon up. The food went down well. It was good fun. Proceeding finished at about 10:30. Ellie, Joey and Lily stayed over.

Harrison playing 'Give Us A Clue'

The Electrocutioners game

Spoons

Girls strength test

title.value: Joey 0 v 8 Ben Football, Katie Date, Carol signing at Old People's home, Gay's Christmas Party

info.content: Mummy and Daddy took a day off work to go Christmas shopping in Basingstoke. Thrilling! Highlight was having lunch outside at the Festival kitchen!

A packed day with the weather looking decidedly dodgy putting pay to Ben's football match.

Instead Daddy could attend parkrun and Chris's 250th attempt and the café after.

Chris Peddle's 250th parkrun

Katie had left the night before to go down to Summer's. They went shopping at Bluewater then stayed in a Premier Inn just the two of them. Summer has here first boyfriend. They spent lots of money getting Christmas presents.

Katie and Summer's shopping haul

Jessica went to Lily's birthday party down in Havant. They did aerial acrobatics, something Ellie has been doing for a number of months.

Jessica doing Aerial acrobatics

Mummy, Daddy, Ben and Ma Ma went down to Bournemouth. They were going to help the Maisey's to move to their new house in Springbourne. They hadn't completed, but were allowed to move stuff across. However, the estate agent was not too forthcoming with the keys. Mummy and Daddy went in to the town while they waited to look about.

We got the keys, and started unloading a van load of stuff. The house was in need of a lot of decoration. It's has a lot of 1950's hallmarks. There was a lot of potential. Loz is going to have his hands full for many months to come.

After some fish and chips and unloading a second load, we all headed into town and the Christmas Tree walk. It was mainly situated in the Winter Gardens. Some massive trees with beautiful lights. We tried to go ice skating but it was all booked up. We went for a bit of après ski in one of the temporary ski huts. Mulled wine. Warms the old cockles.

We headed back to the car via the upside down house. A very nice trip out.

Christmas Tree walk in Bournemouth

title.value: parkrun, Lily's Birthday, Katie at Summer's, Bournemouth Move and Xmas Tree Walk

info.content:
In the morning Daddy, Ben and Jessica travelled over to the Fars on the bikes. Jessica stayed to carry on with her Christmas Present she is sewing with Farmor. A lovely 'I Love You' cushion.

The boys continued on the bikes and went into the adjoining woods. It was quite wet. Ben slipped over whilst pushing his bike up a hill!

Route

Ben MTBing at back of Dettingen Park

At lunch time Katie had her Science tutor. Things appear to be going well on that front. Katie is working very hard with her revision.

Later Daddy and Ben went to the Restaurant at the Packhouse for the Frimley Flyers meal. James made a number of speeches. After 3 hours we only had the main course. We had to skip the deserts. Daddy stood up and made a speech about next years events.

They were collected by the girls and moved on to the Elder lock in. A video / photos of their recent trip to Utah and Colorado. Michael did well editing the video.

title.value: MTB Ben and Daddy, Jessica sewing, Tutoring, FF Christmas Meal, Elder Lock in

info.content:
The weather has been terrible which cost Falcons their fixture this morning. This allowed Daddy to go to parkrun and even a trip to the café afterwards.

After lunch we had planned to go to the cinema and watch the new Harry Potter film and Grinch 2. Due to the weather everyone else had the same idea, and the films were booked up. Daddy and Jess then tried the bowling alley. That too was booked up.

We all returned home and we made a Bingo Christmas card game. We each drew 20 Christmas items and placed them on a bingo card. Each time we open a Christmas card any items that match our bingo cards gets crossed off!

Whilst mummy watch Strictly, Katie went to Kian's 16th birthday house party. There was alcohol involved! Daddy, Jessica and Ben went over to the Fars and played Coppit. Ben won!

Playing Coppit with the Fars

title.value: parkrun, Games, Fars Coppit, Katie house party

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went to parkrun at Frimley Lodge park. First time in a long while. After, still at Frimley Lodge was the big match, Falcons v Alton Huskies. It was a fiercely contested match with Alton taking the lead in the first half, with Tyler equalizing. Joey was making some last ditch tackles in the heart of the Huskies defence. Ben was battling in the centre of midfield. Both had battle wounds at the end of the game. In the second half Alton regained the lead with some dodgy keeping from Cam. Ben popped up later from a corner, used his physical presence (i.e. fouled 2 players) whic allowed him to scramble in an equalizer. Late in the game, Tyler was through 1 on 1 with the keeper and Joey miss-timed his tackle and wiped the Falcons forward out. Joey was booked. The first time we've ever seen a player booked in Ben's football! A proud moment. The game ended 2-2.

Auntie Charlotte had just had her eggs implanted into her, so she had to take it easy. For some reason she thought it would be relaxing around ours so we were happy she stayed the day with us..... along with Len Dog.

The girls made a camp in the lounge and lay and watched films in the afternoon. One was Polar Express. Very relaxing. Later on in the afternoon Jessica's acting academy had an awards evening coupled with 10 acting and singing scenes. Jessica had one to do, but we were very disappointed that it got cancelled last minute as they couldn't find the music. To make up for this Jessica was called out and won a certificate for being a helpful and good member of her class. Well done Jessa.

Jessica's Acting Certificate

title.value: parkrun, Ben v Joey Football, Jessica Acting Certificate, Auntie Charlotte over

info.content:
Daddy gave in and let mummy spend a fortune on carpets!

New carpets

In the morning Daddy joined mummy in church! I know - shock.

There was a split. Jessica and Mummy went on a 3 hour shopping spree in Camberley.

Ben and Daddy went on a Minley Mountain Bike adventure.

Route

Biking near an explosives depot

Ben and Daddy had a Mytchett Falcons match over in Yateley. They only had 10 men so we felt obliged to also only play with 10. Ben played in centre midfield, battling away. He really is improving in that respect. It was a tense finish. 5-2 up, then 5-5. With 2 minutes to go Harvey stuck in a goal to make it 6-5. Our first win in a long time.

After lunch, we departed for walk 103. Katie stayed at home to do some revision and because she lost 0.5kg last week which is not good for her anorexia. Exercise, albeit a walk, wouldn't help. It was from the Berkshire Walk book, so we started over in the Thatcham area again, Donnington Castle. The weather was fine, and we circled Donnington Grove Country club.

Route

Off we go

See Jessica loves a walk

Give us a kiss

Donnington Castle

On our way home we stopped in at Steve and Joyces for a cup of tea and a catch up.

In the evening Daddy and Ben went to the cinema to watch the new Queen film, Bohemian Rhapsody. They both loved it.

Bo Rhap

title.value: Mytchett Falcons, Walk 103 - Donnington Castle, Steve's, Bohemian Rhapsody Cinema

info.content:
Last day and we packed up our bikes and tided up. Daddy went for a quick run. It was hilly and slow. There was nothing left in the legs.

There was a bit of a panic at the house, we couldn't find the second set of keys. We must have spent an hour looking for them, emptying bags, looking all around the house. Fingers were being pointed. In the end Michael had them in one of his bike bags!

The trip back was good. We all went to Gatwick to meet Daddy. As Daddy travelled between the customs and the doors to the outside world he dropped his green bag and lost it! Dipstick.

The weather was terrible and we had some bike issues to sort. Daddy needed brake blocks and a tyre, Tim needed a new front wheel. Eventually we got going up to the peak of Tiede, attempting to get above the rain clouds. Robin had decided to leave earlier and bike up in the rain. Nutter! We caught him three quatres of the way up. He was very wet and cold and welcomed seeing the rest.

Once on top, the boys were just above the rain clouds. They headed off on a 'there and back' sortie, going via the cafe for a spot of lunch. It was beautiful up top and they stuck largely together.

Heading north towards Tiede

Beautiful straight road to Tiede

What a bunch

Route

In the evening they went to the same Restaurant as 3 days previous. Big portions and a lovely meal.

Evening meal at Restaurant

title.value: Teneriffe Biking Day 4 - El Tiede, Ride on top

info.content:
After yesterdays efforts we all wanted something a little less demanding. Another of the routes was the iconic TF12 looping north of Santa Cruz. It was another 1200 metre total climb. There was some stunning scenery on this peninsula. At points looking left we could see the dramatic southern coast, to the right the north coast. We reached the top at El Bailadero however there were no cafes here. A very chirpy girl pointed us in the direction westwards. Daddy set off first, keen to be first for once. However, he raced down the hill on the wrong side of the road. The boys were shouting to get on the right side of the road. However, it fell on deaf ears. Daddy rounded the corner downhill at speed and thought what on earth is that car doing on the wrong side of the road coming quickly towards him. Daddy skidded, the backend of the bike going sideways for a bit. A change of underpants later and he somehow managed to avoid the car!

Some lovely scenery climbing TF12

Hills!

Finally they found a great cafe stop called Casa Santiago and ate Tappas. Almost at the top now and again they split up, leaving Daddy trailing behind..... and bang! Puncture going down the hill. Not only that the same 'valve' problem as before at London Ride 100. The pump kept unscrewing the valve. This was exhausting work. Finally Daddy managed to get going again. Everyone else was waiting a while. Another two miles on. Bang! Not again! A second puncture. He almost threw the bike in the bushes. He cut through some slippery rocks having gone off road attempting to reach the others. Michael took a look and noticed that the brakes block had been scraping against the tyre sidewall and created holes! A boot was made, a second change of innertube and the boys were off and running again.

Second puncture repair

It was all downhill from here and they all stuck together going through the city centre and final stretch of flat where Daddy could confidently put some power down and wasn't last! The finish line was crossed and they collapsed into a beach side bar overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.

Finished and a well earned beer in the bar on the beach

In the evening Bazza made us all a Spag Bol and we all played Killer pool.

Route

title.value: Teneriffe Biking Day 3 - Santa Cruz TF12

info.content:
A lovely sunny day, 22 degrees. A suggested route we decided to follow was the Bradley Wiggins trail from Los Christianos to the top of Tiede, around 2300 metres above sea level. Los Christianos was on the other side of the island. We decided to start by the beach so we were at sea level to begin with. After a bit of a mishap at the start with directions, we crossed north of the TF1 and ascended up Tiede which was the focal point of the whole island.

At the beginning in Los Christianos

Daddy really struggled compared to the others. After just 8 miles he was ready to quit, only a quatre of the way up. Michael had an injury and was taking it easy, so went up with Daddy. They stopped off half way up at Vilaflor for a baguette, coffee and coke and replenish water. The others had nearly reached the top by this point!

At 2200, by the Tiede national park plaque, Michael decided to turn around and head back to the start point to pick up the van. Daddy was determined to continue to the top and continue onto the other side of the volcano.

Reached Tiede park, near the top

Made it Tiede in the background

Reaching the cable cars by the volcano took a lot longer than expected. Five and half hours predominantly in first gear (28 cassette). The final 3 miles had quite an ascent. Daddy was still going up hill after the cable cars. Dusk was forming. The views were amazing. Some sand dunes, strange rock formations and a dried lava river. Fantastic. The light was drawing in quick and as the sun descended and the shadows grew, the temperature dropped as Daddy started his descent down the north side. Cars had there lights on, Daddy unfortunately had no front light and the back had run out of battery. However, not a problem in the semi light, Daddy descended at a steady pace. Within the next mile or two, close to Portillo Alto, the skies were clear and the moon could be seen clearly. Still enough to descend. Now the rocky landscape changed to pine trees lining the roads. This meant what little light there was had now gone. Daddy was freezing, especially on the hands. He was shivering so much it slowed him down as his bike wobbled down the hill. With no light Daddy chose to use the maps on his phone to know when a bend was coming up. Fortunately most of the traffic had gone, but there was still the odd car coming down the mountain. Whenever car lights were seen from behind, Daddy thought it best to stop and go into the side of the road. Daddy had managed to descend about 1000 metres like this.

It's getting darker. I can see the moon

Another car came from behind quite quick and Daddy went to the side of the road on a bend. However, he couldn't see the side of the road and misjudged it. He rode into the gutter \ ditch. He fell off into the gutter, his bike ended on the road, on the bend. Fortunately the car behind swerved around it, the car following also managed to somehow miss it! Daddy picked himself up, brushed himself down. He sustained a bruised elbow and a small cut to the knee. The bike however had a buckled wheel and was un-rideable.

As there was no place to stop, the two cars went 50 yards down the road and then stopped. Both drivers spoke to each other in English. Daddy could hear that they were saying I was stupid for riding down a mountain with no lights.The second was accusing the first of hitting Daddy! Daddy assured them it was his fault and apologised profusely. They both offered to take Daddy down the mountain in the car. Daddy had already international rescue, aka Michael to pick him up. The first driver who was a German tourist offered to take Daddy back to the villa with the bike. A little taken aback from his generosity, Daddy politely refused and urged him to continue on his travels. Michael was an hour away. The German tourist insisted in staying until Michael arrived. He left his car lights on so Michael could see where we were. After conversations about WWII, Brexit and the car industry, he noticed that the car lights dimmed. He tried starting his car, but all that was heard was tick, tick, tick! Oh no. His battery was now flat.

The obvious solution was to push start the car, but both were unsure. What happens if that was not the problem and the car was pushed down the mountain in the pitch black, little on the brakes (servos no power) and no place to rest up if it didn't work. With Daddy's luck he envisaged pushing the German off the mountain to his death!

Michael arrived and with some convincing the car was bump started and all was good. The adventure was over. Goodbyes were said. Michael laughed at Daddy.

Route

Corner I crashed at on the right, but in the pitch black

The boys drove down the mountain into Puerto De La Cruz to pick up the others. Barrie, Nick and Phil had been drinking since midday. They were hammered.

Daddy, Michael, Nick, Phil, Barrie, Steve (Alton), Tim (Alton) and Robin (Alton) all went off to Teneriffe for a few days of cycling. The plane took off late from Gatwick, there were queues at passport control at Teneriffe and a long car journey to the north of the island all meant there was not enough time to do any riding today.

The villa was massive with a swimming pool. Daddy and Michael shared a room together. It was situated just outside Rincón, near Puerto de la Cruz.

View from the villa up to Tiede

Jessica was chosen to be included in the Frimley C of E cross country team. All schools in Surrey Heath were represented. Jessica finished the 2.5km course in 36th place out of 72 runners. Well done Jessica you did very well.

Jessica racing at Lightwater Country Park

Daddy took out Joey and Ben along with the Turners up to Tunnel Hill for a spot of Mountain biking. They tackled the newly found see-saw. Well everyone except Daddy. His wheel kept popping out of the bracket!

Route

Ben mountain biking

In the evening we had the Masey's, Elder's, Weston's and Gay's over for a firework party. There were a number of rockets heading for the sky.

Farmor teaching us to make Aebleskiver

Mummy wanted to get back on to the walks now that Katie is getting a lot better. The walk was out towards the Newbury area, so Daddy seeked an opportunity to firstly go to a different parkrun: Prospect Park. He saw Richard there guiding.

After we headed to Buckleberry Common. There were some road closures which made it not that straight forward. The book isn't great at pinpointing the start at the best of times. There were narrow lanes and mummy got road rage at this old couple in a fat 4x4..... from the back seat. Calm down dear! We headed off on the 2.5 mile adventure. The weather was good and we strolled through the woods.

Route

Buckleberry Common swing

Siblings getting on well

Buckleberry Common walk

After the walk we ventured into close by Thatcham for some lunch. Fish and Chips! Daddy decided to cycle home from here!

Route

The Elders popped by for a bit and Joey and Jessica swapped for a sleepover. Joey is very sweet and polite. Michael said that Jessica is a bit of a nutter.

title.value: Prospect Park parkrun, Walk 102 - Buckleberry Common, Bike Home From Thatcham, Joey Jessica swap

info.content:
Ben and Jessica went out with Yuv and Amerette knocking on doors. They went to a really house in Mytchett where you had to queue up to get into the haunted house.

Scary Ben

Ben was desperate to go to the Fright Night at Thorpe Park. He loved it there. He went with Yuv and Oli whose birthday treat it was.

Ben at Fright Night

We took Summer back to Gravesend. On the way Daddy did a very hilly Lullingstone parkrun in the beautiful hills.

Daddy at Lullingstone parkrun

We popped in at the Teales for a cuppa before making our way down to the Cyclo park. Daddy forgot the helmets! Daddy took all 5 children around the mountain bike course. Then Ben, Jess and Daddy had time trial races around the tarmac surface.

Jessica lining up for a time trial at the Cyclo Park

Jessica went over to the Teales, whilst Summer came here. Ben, Katie and Summer went to Thorpe Park.

Katie and Summer and Thorpe Park
Broadditch Farm haunted house

Our travel back day. We headed off straight after breakfast. We passed through Wrexham. Daddy therefore had to seek the football ground and have a mooch around. Close by was Pontcysllte Aquaduct which we walked along. It was pretty high up and pretty windy. Scary stuff.

Pontcysllte Aquaduct Route

On Pontcysllte Aquaduct

Pontcysllte Aquaduct walk

We moved on down the River Dee down to Llangollen which was a pretty village and stopped for some lunch and again a walk around town. It had a fantastic bakers shop.

Llangollen

We made it home mid afternoon. Lovely few days.

We had a nice cooked breakfast before snaking our way through the picturesque route to Betws-y-Coed and Go Below. Here we had booked in to go on an adventure trip around Penmachono Slate mines which ran for 200 years. We kitted up in wellies and a hard hat and caught a mini bus, southwards. The site was close to Ffestiniog. The slate was also quarried at this site. We could see the rejected slate. We climbed up on the slate, then through the most beautiful wood ever. It was thick with trees, ladened with moss on the trunk. It was almost eerie as we climbed a kilometer or so to one of the modest entrances to the mine. Last wee stop for a few hours!

We entered the mine. Glad we had wellies on as the ground was a mix of puddles and a running stream. We continued to climb and got to a chamber filled with water. The only way to the next stage was to get in the rubber dinghy and paddle across. The guide told us all we needed to know about the slate mine. We had a number of other elements to tackle during our 3 hour stint under ground including: zip wire, abseil and plenty of rock climbs. Interestingly enough we were told to be careful when we stopped for lunch as any crumbs created would turn into lumps of penicillin. There is nothing else to take the debris out of the cave! We finally climbed up a 80 foot ladder back to the surface near to the top of the mine. A great experience in a beautiful part of the country.

Not very accurate Route

The woods where the mine entrance was

Underground boating lake

Rope climbing

Underground abseiling

Out and concerned!

We got back to Rhuddlan and decided to walk to the Castle and mucked about there for a bit. There was a lovely sunset. Opposite our hotel was an American Diner place where we stopped off and ate too much!

Rhuddlan Castle with a lovely sunset

Rhuddlan Castle

title.value: North Wales - Day 3 - Penmachno Mine Caving, Rhuddlan Castle

info.content:
We awoke in Holyhead Travelodge, picked up some breakfast at McDonalds and the local supermarket for those that were a little more health conscious. The weather was turning. Within an hour the rain was coming in sideways. We first headed to Parys Mountain, a copper mine. Due to the weather we were the only ones there. It was an interesting walk. We headed towards the tower, crossed the high bridge and looked at the bleak landscape.

Parys Mountain Route

Parys Mountain

A little further around the coast was Llanbadrig, just north of the most northerly village in Wales! Again another walk in blustery, but dry conditions. We saw a dead fox. Daddy and Katie continued on the walk to the head. We again headed off towards a cafe highly rated on Trip Advisor. It was closed. Closed till Easter!

Llanbadrig Route

Llanbadrig

Llanbadrig

After the dissapointment of not getting food at the cafe, Daddy looked up Trip Advisor and found Pete's Burger Bar... we travelled there only to find it was a burger van! We all laughed at Daddy. Thankfully just down the road was the Bull pub who were doing a Sunday Carvery. Yum.

After our fill, we headed for our third mini walk of the day at a 5,000 year old Burial Chamber in Bryn Celli Ddu. We had fun running up and down the hill, which I guess isn't too respectful. We had fun.

Neolithic Burial Chamber Route

Bryn Celli Ddu Burial Chamber

Within 8 miles was Newborough Beach. A huge stretch of sand with a spit of land reaching out in to the Irish Sea. It was quite picturesque especially with the sky. First dark and cloudy, eventually the sun won through and gave us some nice pictures. Katie and Daddy walked a fair way until Daddy got a hypo so they turned back. Meanwhile Jessica and Ben were playing secret agents.

Newborough Beach Out Route

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

We headed to Rhuddlan for our next hotel, a Premier Inn. Whilst Mummy watched the Strictly results, Daddy went out for a run around the village.

Rhuddlan Run Route

title.value: North Wales - Day 2 - Anglesey - Parys Mountain, Llanbadrig, Bryn Celli Ddu Burial Chamber, Newborough Beach

info.content:
In the morning Daddy did parkrun, then the Falcons lost 9-2 to a strong Windlesham side. We went down to a bare 11 men. Ben really played well, getting stuck in with some tough sliding tackles.He won Man Of The Match. Well done Ben.

We then travelled on the long journey north up to Wales. We stopped off a few times, but reached Holyhead in about 6 hours. We got Fish and Chips and sat on the quayside and saw the ferries which travel to Dublin.

Fish and Chips on Holyhead quayside

Katie had a photography project. She needed some family members and a gloomy beach.

Ben, Daddy, Jess at Southsea beach in the rain

Southsea beach

In the morning the Falcons lost 2-0 to Badshot Lea Ninjas. The game could have gone either way. However, there was an unsavory incident with one of the parents.

In the afternoon, us girls went to Camberley shopping.

In the evening Katie went to Catherine's 16th birthday. It was a house party with alcohol and some boys. Katie came home at 11pm.

Katie going to the party

Party time at Catherine's 16th

title.value: Badshot Lea 2 v 0 Falcons, Shopping, Katie first proper party

info.content:
Katie and Jess stayed in the car from 5pm till 11am the next morning.

Katie and Jess in the car

In the morning, Daddy went off for a bike ride. This time wanting to ride the A331 and the Hogs Back. Mummy went to church. Katie had her second tutoring session, this time on Chemistry.

Farfar popped around and played with Jessica, Ben and Daddy in a game of Hotel.

In the afternoon we chilled out and later Ben and Katie went to Church Youth Group.

Last night Katie went for a sleepover at Summer's. So we went to collect Katie from Guildford later in the day.

In the morning, after Mummy and Daddy's flu jab, Ben and Daddy went off to Windlesham for a match. They were far better than us. Daddy was on his own as Loz was away. It was also Silent Weekend, so no coaching during the match. We ran out 8-3 losers. It tipped it down by the end of the game.

Later, Mummy and Jessica went into Camberley to do some shopping.

Mummy came to collect us from Bournemouth.

Daddy was waiting for the Russian to turn up for him to be told he can't take the bike away! Daddy put his motorbike on Autotrader at £750, listing all the problems with it. The most severe was an oil leak. On Thursday he got a phone call from a Russian chap (Russian 1) wanting to come down from Leicester to see it. He arrived after football training in the dark. He could barely speak English. So bad, Daddy had to send the house postcode by text. The Russian brought his friend along (spoke equally as badly) who almost drove it through next door's front window. They were obviously concerned about the oil leak, but they really didn't have a clue about motorbikes. They liked the bike and offered £700 which Daddy accepted. They paid a £300 deposit and said he'll be back on Sunday morning (today) to collect it.

Friday came along and a short email message came through from a chap called Dimitri asking if I knew where the oil leak was. Daddy replied no, and the chap asked to see the bike that evening. Daddy thought it was Russian 1, given the name 'Dimitri' just wanting a closer look at that oil leak. Dimitri emailed to say he's had a job cancelled in Watford and he come down. Bearing in mind this was Friday night rush hour, he must have spent an hour and a half getting from Watford. He arrived and Daddy soon realized Dimitri was not the same person as Russian 1. Massive dilemma. Does he tell this new chap that there is a mistake in identity. Daddy couldn't do this so explicitly seeing he had traveled so far. Daddy's tactic was to exaggerate the oil leak and all the other faults. He did such a bad job that Dimitri offered the full amount and could pay for it all right now! Arrrgghhh. Daddy couldn't say no - what excuse could he have given? So the paper work was done, the only proviso was that he couldn't take the bike away till Monday, during the daytime. So Daddy gave him the keys to the motorbike so he could just ride off.

Daddy then frantically tried to get hold of Russian 1 to say the deal was off. Citing a problem in Daddy's new bike, therefore needing his old bike. Over a dozen calls and texts were sent during the Saturday and Sunday and no reply.

Daddy was very nervous. What if Russian 1 just turned up, having not read any of the messages, seeing the motorbike in driveway and wondering why he couldn't drive it away. Fortunately, he didn't turn up. Not a peep. Perhaps he'd forgotten.

In the end Russian 1 contacted Daddy a few days later, and was ok about the situation. It then took another week for the deposit money to be returned as there was an issue with receiving SMS texts from him. Daddy feels he got away with that one.

The silver bullet has got to go

Katie has been struggling with science at school, which is partially at the fault of the school and their bad teachers. The tutor, said he tutors many from Tomlinscote! Katie found it rewarding. He charges £35 for the hour.

In the afternoon Jessica really wanted to go Banger racing over in Aldershot. They saw hot rods and caravan Bangers. There were only 4 caravans and they raced in a figure of 8!

Caravan Banger Racing at Aldershot

title.value: Katie Tutoring, Banger Racing, Youth Group, The Motorbike and Russians

info.content:
Busy day, starting with parkrun for Daddy. He has been feeling under the weather with a cold that hasn't shifted, so he took it nice and easy.

Straight after and still at Frimley Lodge Park, the Falcons played Camberley. Ben was well up for the match as a lot of Tomlinscoters filled the opposition lineup. He even went to bed slightly earlier to be fresh for today! The game was physical from the opposition. There was a little bit of needle. We suffered as a result, many of the boys not liking it and not really wanting to play. Part of the managers were thinking the boys have got to get used to this treatment. Some parents really didn't like it. In the end we ended up losing 2-0.

After a speedy lunch we headed down to Bournemouth to see Charlotte. Once the Elders arrived we headed into town to get a Shakeaway. It took forever, but well worth it.. Mummy and Daddy headed home after and we stayed with our cousins and Auntie Charlotte. We played games; code words and linky. We watched Shrek and went to bed at gone 1am!

The Bournemouth Crew

Meanwhile Mummy and Daddy went out for a meal to the Villa Bianca, Frimley.

Villa Bianca

title.value: parkrun, Falcons 0 v 2 Camberley, Bournemouth Sleepover, Villa Bianca

info.content:
We travelled up to Colchester to meet with Mummy's cousin Kerry and husband Simon, along with Pop Pop's sisters and the rest of the Weston crew. It was raining and the first day of it feeling autumnal.

They had gone to so much effort getting huge gazebos up. Jessica and Hattie got on well. The rope swing proved a winner with the boys especially. We had a good laugh resulting in some impromptu Latin party dancing!

The Weston's and derivatives

title.value: Kerry and Simons for a BBQ

info.content:
A busy morning starting off with Daddy running his 250th parkrun (or is it 251st, eh James?). It was nice to see all the well wishers. Daddy ran with Loz to start with and completed the course in an average time of 26 minutes. There was an announcement before the run and photos, cake and a card after the run. All very touching, especially as we all turned up to support him including the Fars. Jessica and Ben ran the last kilometre with Daddy.

Daddy ballooned and carded up

The celebration crew

Fortunately today's Falcons match was at Frimley Lodge Park, so Daddy quickly swapped to manager role. We faced Yateley, who went 2-0 up. A few changes at half time, saw a fight back by the boys and eventually we ran out 7-3 winners. Ben played well as a terrier in midfield.

Jessica heard that Farmor was running the tea bar down at Chertsey T Football Club, so got it in to her head that wanted to go down and help. She took her apron and made herself at home in the tea bar, helping making the teas, coffees and tidying up. She loved it. Chertsey also riding high, top of the table having won every game so far.

Jessica and Farmor tea barring

Later in the evening Daddy went to buy a motorbike from someone at his work's friend. He bought the 4 year old, CB500X for £2250. It is nice to have a bike where everything works, it has heated handlebar grips and a scotoiler. It is noticeably less fast, but more trustworthy around the corners. It has 50,000 miles on the clock. Now we need to sell the old bike.

New CB500X motorbike

title.value: parkrun 250, Falcons 7 v 3 Yateley, Jessica at Chertsey T FC teabar, Bought Motorbike

info.content:
We went over to see Auntie Susan and Graham as it was Susan's birthday this week. We had a cup of tea and sat in Graham's new Mercedes. Loving the internal lights.

In the Tremear's Kitchen

Jessica prepared a speech to the rest of the class in a bid to become House Captain for Endurance. There was a little bit of pressure seeing both Katie and Ben had previously been voted in as house captain. She had practiced her talk a number of times, amending it a bit here and there. Anyway today we found out she had been elected. Well done Jessica.

Exert out of the Frimley Times

title.value: Jessica voted in as House Captain

info.content: The Fars invited Jessica out to see the circus in West End. There weren't too many people in the audience. Jessica had a nice time.

title.value: Jessica and Fars to Jay Millars Circus

info.content:
Daddy set off early for Brands Hatch. He was supposed to be joined by Robin, Michael and Nick, but they all bailed out for one reason or another. Daddy was set the task of doing 100 miles in 6 hours. After the first hour he was 5 to 10 mins ahead of schedule, by 3 hours he was just on time having completed 50 miles. However, he had used all his energy to accomplish this and only managed 30 miles in the final 3 hours. Can't say it was enjoyable, but at least he's done 34 laps of Brands Hatch. He finished 20th out of 51 in his category.

Daddy taking on Graham Hill Bend

Route

In the morning Ben had his first game of the season, away to Hart Tornados. He won 6-0.

As part of Jessica's birthday present she was treated to a trip to London. First off to the Barbican (via the normal Gunnersbury route) to see a fashion show. Expectations were high because it was London Fashion Week. However, they didn't have a great seat, the models were young children and brands, although posh, we hadn't heard of them.

So they skipped out in the interval and headed towards Oxford Street and Regent's Street for some retail therapy..... lasting hours!

Just off to London Fashion Show

Not sure!

Jessica and her balloons

title.value: Hart 0 v 6 Falcons, London Fashion Show, Oxford Street Shopping

info.content: Jessica invited 12 friends over for a party. We hired a big bouncy slide. Amirette stayed for a sleepover.

We started in bed with opening cards and presents..... well mainly cards with money in them. She accrued over £300! Shocking and a very lucky girl. Of course pancakes for breakfast before a day at school.

After school the idea was to go to Thorpe Park. However, a combination of it being shut and Great Grandma being whisked to hospital meant we went to Frimley Park Hospital instead. Great Grandma had fallen over and cracked a vertebrae! She is in pain, but getting on as well as can be expected.

Jessica wanted to go to eat in the middle of a roundabout for dinner. Sound strange eh? Well she is referring to the Shepherd and Flock pub in Farnham. We booked a table and dressed it up with some banners and a balloon. She loved it. Jessica chose the exotic 'beans and chips' option. IT wasn't even on the menu, they were just side orders. We stayed for a while before going for a walk around the 'island'. We decided who in the family should live in each of the 14 or so houses.

In the morning Daddy went out with Bob and Jim for a Guildford circular. The pace was faster than usual which was good. They stopped to watch a few Flyers run in the Pilgrims Half Marathon.

Route

Bob, Jim and Daddy cycling

In the afternoon we relaxed at home and played a new quiz game on our mobiles and PS4. It's called Knowledge Is Power. There are a number of rounds on various subjects. The Maisey's popped around so they joined in a game as well. Jessica won!

Jessica won a family game of Knowledge Is Power

title.value: Guildford Circular Ride, Maiseys Over For Knowledge Is Power

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went to do parkrun. Ben came along but only did one lap as he had to get back and take Jessica for a 1-2-1 football training session. The girls went off to a fashion show in Guildford. High Street shops were the presenters. There were a couple of dudes from Love Isalnd which pleased Katie no end - she went bright red when she went next to them.

Guildford Fashion Show

Jessica's drama group were putting on a show. This was slightly different. The script was first seen by everyone at 7:30pm on Friday. They only had 24 hours to produce it and learn the music and lines. It was Joseph and his Amazing Technicolour Dream coat. There must have been a cast of 40 or 50 ranging from Jessicas age to old adults. Jessica had a small part. We dropped her off at 3pm at the theatre. We all came along with the Fars and Ma Ma and Pop Pop. She loved it.

Jessica in Joseph

New School years:

Katie Year 11

Jessica Year 6

Ben Year 9

Off to school

Ben set the bath off. However it was dinner time. He had forgotten about the bath. When Katie finished dinner and went in to the front room she shouted out that water was pouring down the light and onto the carpet! Oh dear. To coin a en-vogue saying from Ben himself, 'You plonker' Ben. Fortunately there was no lasting damage.

info.content:
We split today. Daddy, Ben, Farfar, Ma Ma and Pop Pop went up towards Milton Keynes to visit Bletchley Park. It was a veterans day and Great Grandma was invited too, however, she fell over yesterday and was not well enough to attend.

The day started registering for the veterans day and grabbing a cup of coffee in the hospitality tent. Ma Ma got talking to one of the hosts who setup a future interview with great grandma to talk about her days at Bletchley Park. We found out that grandma was part of the WRENs working in hut 8 and doing detective work from the messages received. It was said she worked on the Italian and Japanese intercepts. We then toured around some of the huts and saw the exhibits, including a very interesting piece on the war pigeons.

After the buffet lunch, we went on a tour around the part of the house and park. Some very interesting stories. After, we ventured into hut 11 and the Bombe. The machine used to decipher Enigma messages.

Bletchley Park House

After finishing up at Bletchley Park itself, we walked around the corner to the National Computer Museum. Seeing the Bombe gave us thirst to see more, especially Colossus, the first programmable computer. For the hour or so we were there it was very interesting. There was a man describing the Harwell Dekatron computer aka WITCH, which allowed you to see memory registers change values. We also saw Colossus working away, with tape whizzing around. Daddy also got to see many of the home computers of the 80s. We had to wrench him off playing Manic Miner on the Spectrum! A good day.

Colossus computer

Meanwhile us girls went to Thorpe Park. Jessica tried a number of new ride including Stealth.

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to do parkrun. Ben is now regularly beating Daddy. It would be a shock if Daddy finished ahead.

The ugly job of re-felting the shed roof was upon Daddy. He has been putting it off for a while now. £80 of felt. Ben helped getting the old felt off the roof. Hopefully this will stop it leaking now. Although not sure about the nails, leaving gaps for rain water.

We know it's not Mummy and Daddy's anniversary until tomorrow. But tomorrow Daddy is out. Ben, enthusiastically stated that he'll host and cook the meal right from menu planning, shopping, cooking, prep'ing the table and room and washing up. He hired a couple of helpers, in Jessica who made the desert and Katie who made the starter and washed up. It was very sweet of them.

They exchanged presents. Daddy received a waistcoat, whilst Mummy a jumper that she'd asked for. For starters they ate homemade garlic bread, mains was a pasta in a tomato sauce and chrizo, desert was a gin and tonic sorbet with homemade brownies. The meal was delicious, even down to the Rose wine! Thanks guys. Top cooking.

Anniversary Meal

18th year

title.value: parkrun, re-felt shed roof, 18th Wedding Anniversary Meal

info.content:
The weather still wasn't great on this bank holiday weekend. Still we were determined to make the most of it and continue with our trip to the coast. The main aim was to actually use Ben's body board that was bought a while back. Daddy being daddy saw this trip to the coast as an excuse to get the bike out, so we dropped him off in Bordon and he biked down from there.The rest of us continued and first went in the cafe to get some food and drink and then had a go on the funfair with tokens left over from a previous excursion.

When Daddy arrived we met in our usual spot next to the volleyball court. and had a picnic lunch. Then it was time to enter the water. Who was brave? Well Mummy, Jess and Ben were. We did use the body board for about 15 minutes before the cold got the better of us.

We returned home and played a family game of risk. Despite a poor start, Ben came back strongly and won, much to his hapiness.

Lunch on the beach

body boarding it up

In the morning Mummy went down to the lake to join Ellie and Lily and mermaid it around the usual circuit.

As we were away on Farfar's birthday, Auntie Susan and Daddy decided to have a family meal at the Leathern Bottle in Wokingham. The weather was terrible, raining all day which scuppered the supplementary Crazy Golf. However, we spent over 3 hours chatting and eating away. It was good fun.

Leathern Bottle, Wokingham

In the evening we played a family game of Monopoly. This Monopoly was a 'Make Your Own Monopoly' where you could make up your own properties and chance / community chest cards. There were some forfeits like, 'Farfar tells you a long story. Miss a go', or 'Go on one of Mummy's walks, miss a go' or 'Daddy buys a dodgy car, pay £100'. Daddy won!

Sadly it was home day. We handed the villa back at 11am and packed our bags and went to Los Abrogos to scrape the undercarriage of the car on some rocks, oops, and to try some Churros in a local cafe type place. They were OK to eat. We headed up the road and did some supermarket shopping for presents and lunch. We then headed back to Costa Adeje and took a long walk along the promenade to Playa de Torviscas. Here we hired another pedalo boat with a slide. However, it wasn't quite as good as the other day. There were some islands 100 metres from the beach which we all swum out to and had a look.

J and D in sand. for Jessica and Daddy

Ben and Daddy in Costa Adeje

We dawdled back to the car, stopped of for a KFC and McDs before returning the car back at the airport. The flight went well, landing back in Gatwick at just gone midnight. However, because we parked the car a couple of miles away and we were so late, there were no buses, there was no way Daddy would stretch for paying for a taxi, so he decided he could run it! Getting out of the airport was a mission in itself. Or at least getting out at the right exit. Eventually he was out and running up a dark, spooky path with 6 foot high chain link fences either side. At Horley some people who had finished in the pub for the night were wondering why I was jogging at 1am in the morning! Having got back to the car (it was OK), Daddy then didn't do too well at re-locating us at the bus station. We rolled into the house at 2:30am, leaving the suitcases in the car. It had been a long day. Daddy had 5 hours sleep before work next morning!

Back to car route

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 8 - Costa Adeje and Home

info.content:
Everyone was looking forward to this day. The reason we chose Tenerife was because we looked up where the best Water Park in the world was. Siam Park was the answer, so based our whole holiday around this. Mummy had saved £600 to get us all the VIP tickets. This granted us unlimited fast pass entries and unlimited food and drink. The Teale's were also in Tenerife and we met up here to experience the day together.

The big question was going to be whether Ben could get on the Tower of Power. The large, drop slide. The big problem was you had to be 14. When Alice also said you had to be 45kg, Ben was upset and had resigned himself to not going on the slide. There was a bit of phaffing at the start, but by 10:30 we were off and starting our first slide. Mummy was relishing the free food and drink. Having the fast pass was certainly useful. The normal queues were long and would have taken 30 / 40 minutes plus. Fast passes were about 10 minute queues.

Most rides involved an inflatable ring. Many of them needed 2, 3, or 4 people to ride in them. It was great. Having got around to the afternoon having tried all but 2 rides. Probably the best two rides. First up the Tower of Power.

No fast pass on this, but the queue was reasonably short. Daddy was confident that Ben would not pass for 14. He was shocked at the exchange. Attendant: How old are you? Ben: 14 Attendant: Really? Ben: Yes. Attendant: OK then, on you go! Unbelieveable. Ben very happy. Daddy dreading what was coming up. 20 minutes later Ben at the top and the lady gently shoving him down the slide. Daddy followed. Ben's reaction: it wasn't that scary! The second ride was one with a shared inflatable with 4. It went so high up the banked edges. Daddy and Ben went on with some weighty people. We stayed to the end. Daddy and Ben calculated 18 slide goes and a trip on the lazy river and big wave machine.

Jessica and Alice

We were invited back to the Teale's villa just 10 minutes away. It was gorgeous. We even had a go in their pool which was even bigger than ours. We strolled down to Costa Adeje's beach front to get dinner in a restaurant. Very nice end to the day.

Meal out

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 7 - Siam Park, Teales Villa

info.content:
We headed to the north coast. Another challenge for the car, who had to make a number of climbs. Once we had got to the north the roads got even steeper. So steep that the brakes were getting very hot. Daddy could smell them and decided we needed to stop, fearing a brake failure. We needed the brakes. El Tanque and Les Cruces are not for the driving faint hearted going up or down! Definitely the steepest roads Daddy has ever driven. After an hour and a half of driving we eventually we reached the town of Garachico.

Garachico used to be the biggest port in the Canaries until a volcano erupted and destroyed the town. The lava formed these natural rock pools which is used to today by us and other tourists to swim in. Dare devil Ben was finding the highest rocks and jumping in first. The rest of us timidly followed in after him. It was an interesting setup. We played around for an hour or so before heading in to the sleepy town. We walked the picturesque streets via the church and town square. We made it to an ice cream shop to have some much needed cool down time.

We returned to another part of the natural pools. Daddy got stuck right into the rock pools and saw about 50 crabs scaling an isolated rock. There were some massive crabs. They were scared of him which was a relief.

First Swim Route

In the rock pools

After completing the long journey home via KFC (again), Daddy cooked up a BBQ before our now traditional hot tub and swimming pool trips.

Later in the evening Daddy decided he needed to do a local run. Having plotted, what he thought was a 5km run, he began heading north, 5km had passed and he was still heading away from the villa something not right. He passed the end of Tenerife's main runway and was later on the road to El Medano. He had plotted incorrectly. Near the end, he got a hypo which restricted him to run walking the last few kilometers. As Ben would say, 'you plonker Daddy'.

Runway Route

Being a Sunday we found a church for Mummy in Los Christanos. She said it was a good service. Whilst she was praying the rest of us went to the sea front and hired a pedalo that had a slide off the back of it. We had great fun. Ben challenged us to jumping from the top step of the slide. We saw some big ships come in and we had ample of space to play around. The weather again was scorching. At the end of our hour, mummy made it to the beach and swum to join us. We loved it.

Pedalo'ing Route

Finishing on Los Christianos beach

Just outside Los Christianos was the Camel Park. A little, strange place with a slightly eccentric lady running the place. It was nice to experience something a little different. Between the five of us we shared 2 camels. Children on one, adults on the other. There were 6 camels in the caravan, all roped closely together. So close that the camel behind us was less than a metre away from the back of our head. We got intimate knowledge of the camels mouth movements. On occasions they got so close we had to duck out of the way. We headed off on a 30 minute walk, zig zagging along some paths. It was interesting and something to say we had done, but wasn't amazing.

Camel Route

We returned back to base and had an ice cream and a dip in the pool. We then split. Daddy decided he wanted to climb the local Mountana Roja, whilst the rest of us went to the beach where the kite surfers seemed to hang out. Daddy chose the most difficult of routes up the mountain it seemed. He enjoyed the stunning view from the top. The rest of us enjoyed the crashing waves, before being told off for being in the wrong area of the beach. It was reserved for sports people!

Mountana Roja Route

Mont Roja

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 5 - Los Christianos, Camel Riding, Mountana Roja Climb

info.content:
Daddy found a nice treat for us by taking to Amarilla Golf and the Pancake Cafe. We of course had pancakes except mummy who had a full English! It was yummy. We then made our way for a stop off at Los Christianos, one of the touristy hot spots. We walked along the promenade and enjoyed the sun.

Jessica tucking into a pancake breakfast

Aviators

We then headed up the coast to Los Gigantes for a spot of lunch, then down to the harbour and the Dive Centre. We had booked a snorkeling trip under the 500 metre cliffs. We got kitted up and taken out on a speed boat for 10 minutes. We anchored under the cliffs and told to explore. The flippers handicapped some of us. Snorkeling was great. Seeing all the types of fish. The rocks under the sea were a little boring but we had an interesting time nosing around. Daddy retrieved a shell for this girl who dropped it too deep. We were snorkeling for an hour or so before returning back to the harbour and taking on some much needed ice cream.

Route

Los Gigantes coast we explored snorkelling

Daddy had parked up the cliff, seemingly miles away so we sent him to get the car. Our next stop on this road trip was another popular resort, Playa De Las Americas. Here we relaxed on the sandy beach, explored the shopping mall and stopped off at a restuarant for a bite to eat. Jessica and Ben hired an electric mini jeep and terrorized the promenade.

Playa De Las Americas Route

Beauty queen in Playa De Las Americas

Katie on the beach in Playa De Las Americas

Daddy and Katie

Ben on a quad bike on the promenade in Playa De Las Americas

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 4 - Pancake Cafe, Los Christianos, Los Gigantes Snorkeling, Playa De Las Americas

info.content:
We headed to the local supermarket to get breakfast, which mainly consisted of doughnuts and croissants.

Daddy drove us up the east coast, along the motorway to the capital of Tenerife, Santa Cruz. On one side of the motorway a steep incline up the mountains, the other side it was the ocean and coastal landscapes.

We decided to go for a walk first to the food market in the centre of the city. There was a large range of food, like a mini Borough Market. We bought some tomato pasta and some sweeties of course. We then walked to a shopping mall where we Katie bought a swimming costume from the much loved Primark and Jessica an inflatable for the pool.

Santa Cruz Walk Route

Getting ready for the pools

We then entered the purpose made swimming pools. There were two massive pools, one had an inflatable slide. We had a great time here. Daddy decided to go for a Flyers 5km run around the city which took in the large football stadium.

Santa Cruz run Route

We spent most of the day here. At the end, Ben and Jessica played football on a inflatable, water pitch. Ben made a Spanish football friend for a bit. Quite interesting to see the both of them communicate in their opposite broken language.

We made our way home and Daddy cooked us up a nice BBQ, whilst we chilled in the hot tub.

Playing the locals at water football

We left our villa in La Tejita and drove up and up and up again to Mount Tiede. Tenerife all came about from the Volcano Tiede. It must have been an hour's drive, winding our way up. There were no flats and no downhills. It was just up. If we did have the Fiat 500, then we would not have made it. The Clio struggled with the 5 of us in it! There were some stunning views. Us children were stunned that we could drive above the clouds. We stopped a few time to take pictures. Our final destination was the last 500m and the cable car to the top. It was scorching hot. Unfortunately, we needed to book in advance to ride the cable car. No one was that gutted, having seen the length of the queue and the cost. We instead climbed a hill just to the other side.

Route on Mt. Tiede

Looking from Mount Tiede

Mount Tiede

We descended and a few miles down we stopped for a picnic lunch. We were still above the clouds and the sun was 'El Scorchioo'. On our way back to the villa we stopped at a supermarket for supplies and then hit the swimming pool at the villa.

Later in the afternoon we hit the beach, our local beach. It was 600 metres away. It was a course sandy beach and with the strong wind, it made for an unpleasant walk as the sand whipped around our ankles. With wind, comes bigger waves. The sea water was the warmest we've experienced ever. We were having such fun battling the waves. In the end, Ben got himself wedged into the sand and a wave came over him and he bent his back under the water. He was hurt and we had to return back to the villa. Great fun.

Route down to Playa De La Tejita

After some dinner, we headed out to the local big town, El Medano, a couple of miles down the road. We walked around the town, down to the sea front. A lovely walk.

Route

El Medano Family shot

El Medano quay side

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 2 - Mount Tiede, Playa De La Tejita, El Medano

info.content:
For once we had a sensible take off time in the afternoon, so drove to Gatwick and parked in our normal 'housing estate' car parking spot in Carlton Tye, Horley. We caught the bus into the South terminal, then the 4.5 hour BA flight to Tenerife's South Airport. We landed on time, got our luggage, but then the wallet was dropped with about 30 coins rolling out in all directions! Then the rental car was sought after and that's when the real fun began!

Gatwick travelators. Always fun

Mummy had booked a 5 seater car as it clearly stated on the email. We arrived at our car and it was a Fiat 500. A small, four seater car. Oh dear. Houston we have a problem. So Daddy went back to the airport terminal to get a 5 seater car. The Europcar lady behind the counter basically wasn't having any of it and said that's the type of car provided for that booking. Daddy pointed out that the sales said we should get a 5 seater car and it would be illegal for the 5 of us to go in the Fiat as it only had 4 seat belts. The Europcar lady replied when asked Daddy said there were only 4 people. Daddy called her a liar, because he hadn't said that. The voices were raised and anger displayed from both parties. At the 'liar' accusation the lady threatened to call the police. Daddy welcomed, this and invited her to do so. Daddy wasn't going away! The lady turned to her next customer, who was listening to this and served them for the next 10 minutes. Daddy waited patiently. After dealing with the customer, Daddy asked where the police were, so the matter could be dealt with...... she hadn't called them. Daddy said she had therefore lied again! Eventually she allowed the use of her phone (which was not available) so Daddy could speak to customer services. They agreed straight away and after a 10 minute heated discussion between the Europcar Lady and Europcar Customer Services, we were granted a 5 seater, Renault Clio! The Europcar Lady still wouldn't have it, and expressed that we should pay more for a 5 seater car. Daddy responded that you shouldn't falsely advertise. The whole getting the car thing took an hour out of our holiday.

Fiat 500 anyone?

This little incident made us late meeting up with our contact at the villa. It was dark now. We did eventually meet up and the villa was lovely. It had a bed for each of us, a hot tub and a shared, big, swimming pool. We got some local food and it was time for bed.

Daddy ran in the Hart 4 with a strong number of Flyers. It was 4 in a team (Daddy, James, Peta and Oli). There was a 4km lap and they had 4 hours to see how many they could do. Daddy ran 3 laps.

Hart 4 Lap 1 RouteHart 4 Lap 2 RouteHart 4 Lap 3 Route

Hart 4

After 37 hours of work, Daddy finally got his coaching certificate

FA Level 1 Coaching Certificate

A friend from church worked at parliament for an MP and was able to give Daddy and Ben a tour around the place. First, they went up by train (£42) to Waterloo. Ben directed, with his new phone, them to the Imperial War museum. They continued touring around where they had left off 6 month ago. Mainly they saw the floor on the conflicts since 1945.

Imperial War Museum

The pair got lunch and ate it on the wall of the Thames looking on to the Houses Of Parliament, watching all the tourists go by. After, they walked around Parliament Square looking at all the statues and onto Westminster Abbey.

Lunching by parliament

2pm and they made it to Portcullis House, got security screened and met up with James. He's a church friend who works for Gary Streeter MP. He happens to be the chairman of the Christians In Politics group, which James helps on. James's degree in Politics and Theology means this is the perfect job it would seem. However, after 5 years he leaving to train as a vicar.

James first led us through a tunnel, under Westminster Bridge Road, which we didn't realise existed. He began by taking us to Westminster Hall, the only original part of Parliament after the fire in 1834. Through St. Stephens Hall and into the Central Lobby. We first turned right towards the Lords end of Parliament. Everything is red and gold. It was very interesting to hear the stories and protocol. We headed towards the Commons next. At first I thought this was big, then thought how small it was to house 650 MPs. It was interesting to the galleries which you don't see on the TV. Again some interesting points of fact. After an hour and a half we ended back up at Westminster Hall and thanked James very much for his time.

Westminster Hall

We caught a bus and briefly got off at Trafalgar Square. Ben was very pleased to see London again. Because of Katie's anxiety over London we generally don't go up much these days. Ben loves it. They continued on the bus past Piccadilly Circus and up Regents Street. They disembarked went in the Bose shop and visited all 5 floors of Hamleys. Harry Potter and Lego are still the big sellers. They walked through Carnaby Street, visiting some sports shops before hitting Nike Town at Oxford Circus. The initial purchase was made for a school bag. We then went into many other sports shops. Ben loved it as there were all the shops he could hope for, and they were all the flagship outlets, which meant they were big. Time was marching on and they were both fatigued from their excursion. A tube ride took them back to Waterloo. They were then able to train it back home.

Various London bits

title.value: Parliament Tour, Imperial War Museum, Oxford Street retailing

info.content:
Ben turned into a teenager today. We woke late and began the present opening process. Well there weren't many of your traditional presents, mainly cards with money in it!

As a treat we went to Farnborough Gate McDonalds to have some breakfast. Ben had pancakes with maple syrup with orange juice. His favourite.

All sorts of things on Bens Birthday

We shortly went up to London for a surprise treat. We parked up at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic park and went to the ArcelorMittal Orbit, the big red, scaffolding looking structure next to the stadium. First we had a picnic next to the 'Orbit'. We had booked to go on the slide. It takes about 45 seconds to go down it. It was very quick.

The ArcelorMittal Orbit

The slide

We rushed back to host Ben's football birthday party. Dad had made some points based system, with 3 football matches, a game of World Cup and a penalty shoot out. There were 7 others: Oli, Kieran, Jamie C, Freddie, Jayden, Jonny and Joey. After we came back home, had pizza and played in the pool.

In the evening Ma Ma and Pop Pop popped over, then the 5 of us watched Ben's choice of film, Mission Impossible 5.

We left on Saturday down to Wareham to the campsite we went to 2 years ago. We left Daddy at home!

  • Saturday: camp setup
  • Sunday: Rained all day. We went to Auntie Charlotte's and watched a film
  • Monday: Lyme Regis

    Us and our cousins

  • Tuesday: Wild swim and Puddletown tea shop
  • Wednesday: Camp, swimming pool and Swanage fireworks
  • Thursday: Studland Bay

    Jessica paddle boarding

  • Friday: Dancing ledge sunrise, Mud park, Durdle Door

    Jessica through the mud course

    The boys and Durdle Door

    The girls at Durdle Door

  • Saturday: Home time

    Hello campers

This is a bit of a sob story. Not sure whether to laugh or cry. Myself and Michael had entered the Prudential Ride 100. A 100 mile bike ride, starting and ending in London. As a back-drop to this, I had not done any distance training, and I had the Thursday and Friday off work due to feeling rundown, sore throat and a headache. So going into this I was concerned about my overall physical state.

We had to register on the Saturday at Excel. The traffic around to the opposite end of the M25 meant it was touch and go whether we'd make the 5pm deadline. The journey involved going in Michael's mobile gas chamber. There is a fault, such that exhaust fumes go into the car, so we had to roll the windows down. With just a few minutes to spare, we dumped the car in a pub car park close by, hoping we wouldn't get clamped. We got in just in time. Even managed to get some cheeky photos in.

At the show

We made our way to the hotel, 'rebuilt' our bikes and watched the Tour De France highlights. After, I went out to the supermarket to get some supplies from Tesco. Got on the bike went around a bend and almost fell off. Rear puncture! Great one of my two inner-tubes used up before I'd even started! Eventually rode the 1.5 mile trip past Excel to a Tesco Express. There were a lot of people shopping and milling about outside. I was a little nervous at leaving the bike right outside, so wheeled it down a barrier'ed slipway to a car park. I went in got yogurt, milk and some fruit. I was panicking a bit, so quickly went out to check. The bike was still there. I went back in again to pay for the shopping. Must have been 2 or 3 minutes. GONE. Bike was nicked.

Where has my bike gone. Site of crime!

I knew there was no chance finding it. It would have been long gone. I did look around, but nothing. I wasn't so worried about the bike so much, but it had my timing chip on it and the bracket / clips for my lights which are going to be hard to replace. Also, what was I going to tell Michael? I started the long trudge back to the hotel and was resigned to the face I wasn't going to do the ride. It was now 9:30pm, I entered the hotel and told Michael what had happened. After he stopped laughing, he hatched a plan which would involve driving 1h 45 minutes back to Alton to pick up his spare bike and drive all the way back again. So windows down in the car for a 3.5 hour round trip plus a bit extra as the bike had no pedals and needed a tweak here and there.

On returning back, I managed somehow to lose the hotel entry card. So we needed to call the receptionist, issue us a new card. We just needed our beds. As soon as we got in our room, I went to the toilet and pressed what I thought was the cord for the light switch. As it was a disabled toilet, it wasn't a cord for the light switch, instead it was the emergency cord! Oh dear. A mini-siren sounded, a flashing red light out the room and the receptionist running towards us. Again this is 2:30 in the morning! After apologising and setting the phone alarm for 2 hours 10 minutes time we finally went to sleep.

4:40am and the alarm went off. What were we doing? Gulped some breakfast down, managed to lose the second of our room cards, and took our stuff out to the car. Michael hid his car key on the tyre of the car, misjudged it and the keys clattered inside the wheel. We just left it for now as we were running behind schedule. The weather was a little nippy as we rode the 6 miles to the start line. The scale of the operation was vast. 29,000 riders all starting from the same area. Myself and Michael, not only had different start times, but also were starting at opposite ends of the Queen Elizabeth Park. So I decided to try and sneak in and start with the 'Greens' at the earlier time.

It was 7:05am and we were finally off. It was nice to get going finally. Within 15 minutes the heavens opened and for the next 8 hours it rained and rained. We hooked on to some fast trains as we snaked our way through London and finally out into the countryside. My 'new' bike was great. Loved it. The seat post needed adjusting, but otherwise the ride was much better than my Giant Defy.

To the Tower

Michael picked up a puncture around the Byfleet area. The stop and the rain made us a little cold so we stopped in for a coffee. We got to Newlands Corner and stopped for a bit, before heading down the fast descent down towards Gomshall. As I raced down, Pssstttt. A wobbly front wheel made me almost lost control as I had a blow out. Damm it, another puncture.

Puncture going down Newlands Corner

My turn. We must have spent over 30 minutes trying to sort this out. We had a problem. We changed the tube, pumped it up and as we unscrewed the pump, the valve unscrewed with, making the air come all out. We must have tried 2 or 3 times. It really is exhausting stuff trying to get enough pressure into the tubes. Michael ingenious idea was to tighten the valve to the inner-tube by trapping it in the rear axel with the use of the quick release. This worked a treat and finally we pumped the tyre again, and off we went. Better still there was a track pump just up the road to get me up to the ideal pressure. Also a chap sold his spare inner tube as we had none between us and we hadn't much luck so far. Then down the next hill again and Pssssttttt. Arrrrgghhhh. Another puncture in the same wheel. Something fishy going on now. The tyre sidewall had eroded a bit. We worked out that the brake block was set too low and was rubbing against the tyre, causing the punctures. We happened to fix the puncture at the bottom of the road leading to Netley House, my company's old premises. Again quite a time was spent re-enforcing the tyre with a gel and getting the tyre pumped up. It was still hammering down with rain. Again we were down to no spare inner-tubes between us and now I couldn't use the front brake. We were just entering the really hilly section now!

At this point, chucking the bike in the hedge was looking appealing

We were diverted past Leith Hill as someone had a heart attack and CPR was being administered by the paramedics. That explained the various ambulances and medical vehicles screaming passed us. I found a track pump, but rather than making things better it made them worse as all the air escaped. It was a rubbish pump. I managed to get back to 40 psi, but it was less than half inflated. It was slow going through Dorking due to the traffic. The organisers had shut Box Hill due to an accident. So we avoided both main hills and it meant we were only going to do 90 miles, not 100. At the next stop there was a bike shop. Yippee.. I managed to get full pressure again in my tyre, but they had sold out of inner tubes. With 25 miles to go we hit another blockage in the road at Leatherhead.

Held up in Leatherhead

The rest of the journey back to London was quite pleasurable. The weather started to clear and as I hadn't actually felt we had started, I had plenty of energy to push some pace. We finished at goodness knows in what time. It was largely irrelevant.

Finishing down The Mall

The Medal shot
