We collected our medals, took some photo's and headed back to City Airport. However, we were determined to do 100 miles. Considering we had done 6 extra miles to get to the start line, we decided to ride back to Tower Hill and catch the DLR. I made it back home at 8pm. What a journey the past 28 hours were. Because my timing chip was stolen it hadn't counted officially, so that means I got to do it again another year. I'm chasing the London Classic medal.

Route

Summer came over to stay, whilst Jessica went over to the Teale's. Jess went to the beach at Bluewater.

The majority went over to Fiona's and played in their pool along with Helen and Guy.

Mummy subjected to an attack

title.value: Summer here - over to Burrows, Jess to the Teale's

info.content:
Katie turned 15 today. Shock, horror, the standard format of eating breakfast in Mummy and Daddy's bed has been temporarily postponed! The present opening did happen. And there were loads. The main present was her new IPhone7+. Katie was mightily pleased after begging for one for months.

After the present opening, we all went into Camberley and surprised Katie by going in Frankie and Benny's for breakfast. We were just about the only ones there, but we had a nice time nonetheless. We all sang happy birthday after having polished off our brekkie.

Frankie And Benny's for breakfast

When we returned Auntie Charlotte came over with Lenny. She took Katie and Jessica out to get their nails done and buy them a subway lunch in Camberley. Whilst the birthday girl was out, the rest of us dressed up the back garden with banners and got the bouncy castle up and running. A couple of Katie's friends popped in to give presents and say happy birthday.

At about 4:30pm our guests began to arrive for a party. The guests included the Elders, the Fars, Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We ordered in Dominos Pizzas and had lots of goodies to eat, including a birthday cake. The party was in full flow and somebody suggested we make a circuit up which included the bouncy castle and running or walking it blindfolded. It was like the ministry of funny walks. It was very funny to see peoples attempts. Ma Ma almost dug into next doors garden! That entertained us for almost an hour!

Singing happy birthday as Katie blow birthday cake candles out

One of Katie's bucket list items was to sleep under the stars. Most of us stayed behind and gave it a go. However, there were a lot of mozzies about. Many of the adults gave up some part of the night, but all the children managed to last till dawn. Katie had a really good birthday.

Sleeping under the stars

We headed towards Cullompton and Diggerland, Devon. Daddy was a little worried at the target age group for this attraction. There weren't many cars in the car park at 11am. Still we eventually got in after a bit of admin trouble from our end concerning vouchers. There were a dozen or so rides and things to do. We enjoyed them all. Jessica and Katie drove a Land Rover and a JCB for their first times. Daddy even drove a JCB for the first time. Jessica was pretty competent for a first attempt. She wasn't phased at all.

We had a go at using the claw and actually digging a hole in a JCB, as well as some games in mini diggers. Quite difficult controlling the arm and claw. Ben was enamoured by the 'Crazy Carts'. Small, electric powered carts with trolley wheels. He wanted one for home!

We tried everything out and made our way home to end a lovely, family weekend.

Placing tyres

Tip trucks

Jessica digging for gold

Mummy v Katie 10-pin bowling

This was Daddy's birthday treat. We were heading down to Torquay for the weekend. Of course on the way we had to stop off at a parkrun. Montacute House is National Trust venue which hosts the Yeovil parkrun. It was double hot as Daddy went on his own around the 5km course. There were plenty of sheep, some there I am sure to trip you up by running right across the traffic of parkrunners. Daddy came in at 26:45 which he was pleased about.

Montacute House

Onwards to Torquay, more specifically Oddicombe Beach where we stopped off for a spot of lunch on the pebbles. We then walked along the coastal path to Babbacombe beach and then up the 30% gradient road back to the car.

Jessica on the way to Babbacombe Beach

We were advised to come up the wrong way up a one way street because the other access was shut...... well we were slightly mis-advised as the road had re-opened. Needless to say we faced an oncoming car. Whoops.

We met Charlie, our guide for the coasteering session. We squeezed into our wet suits and buoyancy aids and headed down into Anstey Cove. It was a reasonably quiet and secluded cove with no obvious public access. We climbed around the fence and jumped in. Katie stood on the sidelines not sure about what was ahead so dipped out of this one.

The rest of us spent the next two hours swimming from rock to rock to cliff and jumped off various ledges and boulders. Some high and some not so high. There were a couple that Mummy, Daddy and Jessica were unsure about. However, we all managed the jumps in the end. Poor Ben got stung a couple of times by a Compass Jellyfish. You could see them from the ledges in their bright orange clothes!

We got some great photos from the experience. One that comes highly recommended.

The coasteering crew

Group jump

Rock climbing

We then headed to our hotel. A Travelodge near Exeter on the M5. We got ourselves cleaned up and then headed out again for Fish and Chips..... as well as an Indian for mummy. We then drove to the River Exe and ate them on picnic benches.

River Exe'ing

Daddy and Ben went to Frimley Lodge park for the Frimley Flyers Handicap event. The competition rules were very different. This year who had to predict a time that you were going to run 5km, and then without a watch or any timing device had to run that time. Ben had chosen to run 26 minutes and Daddy 27 minutes dead.

We were all let go in intervals, in theory we all cross the line together. Out of the thirty two running, Ben was just 7 seconds slower than his predicted time. Daddy was 5 seconds too quick and came in 7th and 6th respectively. Bob and Alfie were spot on with their predictions and were joint winners.

After, we went over to the BBQ pits and had a BBQ, prize giving and a game of rounders. By this stage Mummy and Jessica had joined us. Daddy scored the winning rounder!

Flyers at our handicap event

In the morning Daddy and Ben did Frimley Lodge parkrun in 26 minutes.

Route

Charlotte came over to stay for the weekend and we all decided to use the Wild Swim book she got us. There was a reservoir over in Ceasers Camp. It was a long walk to get there and once we did we found it was out of bounds to swimmers! Gutted.

The unlucky would be swimmers

title.value: parkrun, Failed Wildswim, Charlotte stay over

info.content:
Katie, Ben and Jessica all go to the trampolining club every Monday. Tonight was the end of season competition. Jessica was placed in a higher ability group than Ben and was awarded a bronze for her performance.

Ben was awarded a gold medal for his jump.

title.value: Ben and Jess in Trampolining Competition

info.content:
Jessica has been going to the acting group for about 5 months. Each week she has been practicing her lines and role as Lord Capulet, Juliet's Father. She did every so well with her lines. She must have had 20 or so. Auntie Ellie, Joey, Lily and Farmor all came to watch too. The production, at Camberley Theatre last for about 40 minutes and all the actors were 13 or younger. Katie's friend Katherine was part of the production staff. Well done Jessica.

The boys rushed back to watch the England game in the semi final of the World Cup.

Jessica as Lord Capulet

Daddy turns 43 today. We made breakfast for him in bed and gave him his presents. From Mummy we are going on a Coasteering weekend in a couple of weeks time. From Ben, Daddy got a bumper Tour De France pack which included a big magazine, water bottle, socks and energy tablets. Katie got some veg crisps, Marmite crisps and a nice t-shirt. Jessica got Daddy a nice new belt. From the Elders Daddy got some 3 peaks bits, Susan got Dad some nice swim shorts and beer preserve.

In the evening we had a lovely Lasagne, one of Dad's favourites and he relaxed watching the France v Belgium World Cup semi final match.

Daddy opening 43rd birthday presents

So things have moved fast. Today all five of us went to the Eating Disorder clinic in Epsom where we had a 3 hour meeting talking about Katie's condition. They were assessing whether they would take us on for a 6 week course of treatment which largely involves giving advice and helping Katie get back to a healthy weight. The meeting involved the Nurse, a psychiatrist and a student nurse. In fact Mummy knew the psychiatrist from a talk she gave a few weeks previous on the very subject matter. The nurse also lived in Mytchett and had a son who goes to Tomlinscote and is in the same year!

It was very hard to hear Katie's account. It boils down to body image. The trigger point happened in February. A number of contributing factors include: Being called fat by one of her friends, body image pressure, looking up to friends who have a thin figure, seeing on the internet that you shouldn't eat after 7pm, sometimes bored after school, thinking we were too poor to buy food and probably lots of other things. Daddy cried in the meeting - when Katie was out of the room, it distressed him greatly. Mummy was obviously very concerned and anxious as well. Jessica and Ben contributed as well in the meeting and had a role to play.

We were told that BMI was not used as a measure in children. Instead they use some other height vs weight measurement. It was expressed that 100% is a normal, healthy weight. They recommend children should be between 95% and 105%. At 80% they recommend that the child should be taken out of school. Katie was just above that at 81%. Very concerning. The solution was simply to load calories. Avoid anything that takes away the calories such as exercise. 3000 calories was suggested. 3 meals a day, 3 snacks a day and a pint of 3% fat milk (blue top).

The clinical team went away to meet and they agreed to take Katie on. Initially for a 6 week stint to get her weight back. After that, depending on how she is doing, some psychiatric treatment will be given.

It was quite a session, but at the end of it, we had acceptance from Katie and we felt we had a plan going forward.

After, we went into Kingston and went to Pizza Hut to eat the unlimited buffet. We walked around the shops and got a few bits and pieces for the house and bought the English version of Monopoly, after having the American version for so long.

WE LOVE YOU KATIE.

Daddy joined Auntie Ellie, Rachel, Jon, Loz and Michael on a massive road trip around Britain, with a few mountains thrown in for fun too. They set off on Friday at about 5pm, arriving for a 5am start at Ben Nevis.

The mountaineering was tough. The challengers were certainly putting a sweat on. It was shorts and t-shirt weather even where the snow was and even at night. The weather was hot to say the least.

Driving

  • Alton to Ben Nevis: 528 miles
  • 3 Peaks Route: 463 miles
  • Snowdon to Alton: 252 miles
  • Total: 1,243 miles

Mountains

  • Ben Nevis
    • Start Time: 5:01am - Peaked: 8:06am - End Time: 10:24am (Up: 3h 5m, Down: 2h 18m)
    • Ben Nevis Route
  • Scafell Pike
    • Start Time: 4:53pm - Peaked: 7:28pm - End Time: 9:35pm (Up: 2h 35m, Down: 2h 7m)
    • Scafell Pike Route
  • Snowdon
    • Start Time: 2:20am - Peaked: 4:55am - End Time: 7:36am (Up: 2h 35m, Down: 2h 41m)
    • Snowdon Route

The crew got back to Alton mid afternoon on the Sunday. Exhausted and barely able to walk, but satisfied of their weekend's achievements.

Scafell Pike

Ben Nevis

Snowdon

Snowdon - We did it

We went to church as usual, Mummy was on Sunday school. She was running late, so entered the church service and sat in one of the pews. For Sunday School she needed a microphone so the children could be interviewed. The nearest we had was Ben's megaphone which was accidentally left on. This unknown to anyone played havoc with the church's sound system and basically provided feedback. The feedback was so loud, the congregation were blocking their ears. Unknown to anyone the megaphone was the cause of this problem. Some stand in engineers were up on ladders, fiddling around with cables attempting to fix the problem. They even switched off the sound system and yet the feedback was still reverberating around the church. It was then decided that the service could not continue inside, so it was decided that the service should be held outside.

As Mummy went to leave the church to go outside with the others, she picked up the bag and all of a sudden the noise stopped for a bit, and the pitch of the squeal changed. At that point she knew the cause of the problem. The Megaphone!

Instead of owning up or even just removing the bag, mummy panicked and just left the bag inside the church and joined the service outside.

After 10 minutes Mummy had to leave the service to do Sunday school and made Auntie Charlotte go and get the bag which was in church. However, the men who were busy attempting to find the source of the problem were still there. Mummy told Charlotte to grab the bag and quickly escape. Instead, once the bag was moved it became very obvious to everyone the source of the problem! As no one knew her, she just owned up and said it was her sister's and then sheepishly sloped off. After Sunday school we all ran home without talking to anyone.

The parishioners later were gossiping about the silly girl who brought a megaphone into church. I mean who would do a thing like that.

title.value: 3 Peaks Challenge - Mummy Caused Church Evacuation with Megaphone

info.content:
Whilst Daddy and the Elders were away doing the 3 peaks, Mummy looked after Toby, Lily and Joey. She took them to the RLC Army show at Deepcut. It was very hot. On the parade ground we saw motorbikes do a display. Toby loved that. We also had a go on the fairground for a bit. It was far too hot so came home shortly after.

Meanwhile Ben went with some Tomlinscoters up to Alton Towers. It was a trip for the well behaved. It was a reward for their efforts of the year. You didn't go unless you were a good boy or girl. Ben managed to go on just 4 rides, spending a lot of his afternoon in front of a big TV screen watching England beating Sweden in the World Cup quatre finals.

Back at home again, Mummy took us to the Hale Carnival with Ma Ma and Pop Pop.

Kaite at the RLC Army Show

title.value: RLC Army Show, Ben to Alton Towers, Hale Carnival, Elders overnight to stay

info.content:
Jessica competed in three running races. She was the final runner in the relay and won!

Jessica starting her race

The highs and lows of being a parent. In the evening we went to an awards ceremony at Tomlinscote School. Pupils from all years of the school were present to pick up awards from different subject area. There were just two awards for maths in year 8. Ben won his for attainment. A fantastic achievement. He went onto the stage and received the award from the Head Of Maths and from a guest speaker. Well done Ben we are very proud of you.

Ben receiving his award

The previous day, Ben was selected to go on a Maths and Computing exercise over in Crowthorne. He didn't enjoy it very much. He likes to be thought of as a geek, but does not like all the other geeks because they are too geeky. Now that's logic that no-one understands.

Over the past couple of months, Katie's weight and diet has become a concern. The lack of food intake has been minimal and what is being consumed has all been healthy stuff. She has been having fruit for breakfast, skipping lunch at school (because she hasn't time) and then not eating much for dinner. No snacks either. Today and last night it all came to a head, and Mummy took her down to the GPs where she was diagnosed with Anorexia. She is 43kg and her height is 163.5cm. The GP has referred her on, and in 2 weeks we have a follow up appointment for bloods. Katie does not like speaking about it and has been in denial about it. Today, however, she recognises there is an issue and is positive about resolving it. She loves 'planning' at the moment. So we popped to Hobbycraft and purchased a large piece of card. Katie has looked up meals and snacks that she would like and has written them on cards. So for each day of the following week she knows what she is going to have at breakfast, lunch and dinner. She also has a snack card. She seems quite determined to follow the plan. She says she feels a lot happier and that she has turned over a new leaf. This week at shopping she went around the supermarket and got all the ingredients for the menu's she has devised. We are very proud how she wants to turn this around.

title.value: Ben Top Of Year for Maths, Katie Anorexia

info.content:
In the morning we made an early start on this gloriously sunny summer's day. We made our way down to the Mytchett lake where we swum. Daddy came for the first time, and I think we'll leave him behind because he was so slow and struggled to do 500 metres. Katie and Mummy whizzed around. Jessica even beat Daddy back. It was a busy lake. There must have been over 100 swimmers during the morning.

Mytchett Mermaids and Mermen

After Mummy went to the early church service, we headed to Cookham, just the other side of Maidenhead for walk 101. Daddy loved his new walking boots. It was a very hot day. Katie has been converted to a walking lover, not a hater. DoE has changed her she said.

Holy Trinity Church, Cookham

As it was what we thought was to be the 100th walk we decided to stop off for lunch at the Bounty pub half way around. It was only later that Daddy miss-calculated (really it was walk 101). Just to think walk number one was completed on 31 December 2010. 7.5 years later we get to 101! The walks have larger been taken from a number of children's walking books: London, Surrey, Hampshire and Berkshire. We still have 21 to complete before all the walks have been done in all the books.

After passing some cows who took refreshment in the Thames, we finished the walk hot and bothered and needed to get home for some ice lollies and iced water.

We met cows who went for a swim

Daddy and Katie going through a farmers field

Route

title.value: Mytchett Mermaids and Mermen, Walk 101 - Cookham

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went with Ben to a very hot and well attended parkrun. 670 runners. They battled through the traffic and came in at 27 minutes.

Ellie was 40 today and to celebrate she hosted a BBQ with the invite list restricted to the Barnett family members. We had a good time playing in the back garden with the water. She got a Mini Clubman as a present from Michael!

After work Daddy went to Elstead and ran the 'marathon' for the 2nd time out of the 106 that have been run. The run includes some sandy parts and because of the exceptionally dry, hot weather. There were dust clouds as the leading runners passed. Daddy had to jump a gate, go over some very rough farmers ground and of course a splash across the River Wey. A cracking event, with a short pub trip after.

The river crossing

Liquid refreshment

It was the final group game for Denmark which they need to get a point in order to qualify. Daddy took half a day holiday and went around to the Fars house to watch the France game. Aftr school both Jessica and Ben arrived. It was a fairly drab match, but we enjoyed ourselves there.

Jessica not watching the game sharing a joke with Farmor

Mummy's 42nd Birthday. We started the day in bed opening presents and cards. From Daddy she got the weekend away in Flamingo Land. From Jessica she got a charm for an impending bracelet. Katie got some clothes. Auntie Susan some shorts and a top. The Fars a frying pan and a camping bucket thing. Ellie and Charlie a Pandora bracelet.

Birthday treats in bed

Ben made a treasure hunt where he hid 16 bars of chocolate around the back garden which Mummy had to seek out. Mummy had the day off, but didn't do anything special. In the evening she took us to trampolining whilst going to Palettes.

We had an early 5am departure from Frimley Green for our trip to Yorkshire. We made it for the 9:30 gate opening and plotted our route around the half theme park, half zoo. Jessica wanted to do her first upside down rides. Before now she has been too small, but the restrictions here were generous. She was tentative on the first ride, Hero where you lie on your front and get whisked around upside down. However, she managed to pluck the courage up and went on Mumbo Jumbo with Daddy and loved it. There was no stopping her now. We managed all the white knuckle rides, well except Daddy who couldn't take any spinning around. There were some firm favourites, like Velocity and Kumali. I don't think many enjoyed the high chair-o-plane ride.

Jessa looking beautiful

Posers in the park

In the afternoon we walked around the zoo bits. Mummy was fascinated with the hippos. We perched on a viewing platform so had excellent views of the hippos in and out of the water.

We took a cable car back to the main theme park, where Ben, Jess and Daddy went to play laser quest. Daddy went out within 5 minutes, Ben 7 minutes. Jess must have lasted 15+ minutes. I think her tactic was to hide and hide good. She was very proud of her achievement of lasting longest.

We scrabbled around in the last half hour to fit in as many rides as possible. It was a good day. A smallish park, witch was not packed out like a Thorpe Park and kept us entertained all day.

Real life Call Of Duty

We trundled off and stopped at Malton and ate Fish and Chips by the river. It was a glorious evening. We then had a 45 minute drive to Leeds where we had a hotel for the night. We were all fairly bushed. We watched the end of a very tense Sweden v Germany World Cup game.

Katie has arranged to do a week's work experience at Loseley Park. It is centred around events planning which is close to the wedding planning that Katie eventually would like to go in to. Today was her first day and she dressed appropriately, got there in time for the 9am start and began work! She was looking forward to the experience very much.

Katie just before work

Here tasks through out the week involved:

  • Monday: Group interview for front of house staff. All applicants passed. Katie did some data entry on employees profiles.
  • Tuesday: More data entry and a couple of meetings with couples who are having their wedding at Loseley Park. They were discussing menus and costs.
  • Wednesday: Serving guests in the tea room as well as more meetings.
  • Thursday: Bike BBQ where there was a lot of washing up and clearing of tables. There was also some office work on a computer. The accounts lady offered Katie a summer job!
  • Friday: Tours around the house itself.

Employers Report

Daddy woke and eventually he got some breakfast in bed!!! There were some presents floating about including some chocolate, veg crisps and a wallet to replace the one that Daddy dropped down the toilet whilst he was doing a poo!

Daddy

Us 3 stayed in and missed church. Auntie Charlotte popped by to pick Lenny up as we looked after him yesterday and overnight.

Daddy went on a long bike ride. He left without a plan and ended up having to rush back for 1pm. He managed 40 miles around the Bracknell and Windsor areas. He tested out his new rucksack in preparation for the 3 peaks.

Route

In the afternoon we all went to Petersfield to go strawberry picking with the Westons and Elders. We manage to eat as many strawberries in the field as we paid for. We got 2 punnets, had a cup of coffee, saw a load of posh people and made our way home.

Strawberry pickers

In the evening Daddy went off with Farfar to play croquet over at St Johns. Daddy won and played reasonably well, making some nice breaks. His hitting in was still a bit wayward. It was nice to see Barry Huxley who Daddy hasn't seen for over 20 years!

Dad playing Farfar at croquet

Daddy and Ben went off to parkrun and shifted around in slightly slower than average pace.

Ben beating Daddy at parkrun

There were four World Cup matches on today. The third of which was Denmark v Peru. And for that special reason we had Daddy's friends around for a World Cup BBQ, with WAGS. Daddy went out to Costco yesterday and got £180's worth of stuff.... which Mummy thought was excessive.

We had the usual food fare and the same level of mayhem with a mix of children running about. The boys tried to do keepy-upys. They were rubbish! They've certainly lost any talent they might had once had. We sort of watched the football. Denmark won 1-0. All the WAGS got on very well with each other.... in fact it was a lovely afternoon. We finished at about 10pm.

Carnage

title.value: parkrun, Denmark v Peru World Cup BBQ

info.content:
James poked his head into the tent at 3:30am. Martin you're up in 20 minutes. Great Daddy thought! It was a nice time, because it was the first lap where the torch was not needed. Dawn was breaking and the birds were twittering away. The third lap of Daddy's was slow again at 50 mins.

Ellie finished her lap and effectively her Endure24 2018 with another solid effort. She did a fantastic 15 miles. She said she enjoyed it enough to come back another year. Woo Hoo.

Although the knee was hurting Daddy had one more effort at around 10am. He felt he ought to do 4 laps otherwise would feel unfulfilled. He made amends with his relatively slow lap 2 and 3 efforts with a 46 minute 4th lap to complete 20 miles. He could barely walk after as he put so much effort in.

Daddy horsing around

We all crossed the line together as a team and collected our medals, had photos and went to take the tents down.

Overall a very enjoyable weekend. Ben wanted to come back and do more laps. Auntie Ellie wants to do it again....and Anthony enjoyed it. Jury is still out whether he wants in for 2019.

Lap 3 Lap 4

Daddy and Ben medalled

This year the Frimley Flyers entered 3 teams into the Glastonbury for runners. Yesterday Daddy and an army of tent erectors went to prepare the site for 30+ runners, friends and family. This year Daddy wasn't on is own. He had Ben, Auntie Ellie, Joey and his friend from work; Anthony.

Tent setup

Team lineup

Daddy and Ben arrived at about 11am, met up with everyone, made introductions, did the obligatory photo shoot and away the Flyers went.

Daddy smashed around the circuit in 43 minutes which was his quickest since 2015. He was happy with that, although there was still knee pain. Anthony went sub 40 minutes and Auntie Ellie threw in a steady 48 mins. Ben was desperate to run, however there was a bit of talk of disqualifying teams who raced with non registered runners. So we decided against it until night fall. At around 11pm Ben went out for his first ever 5 miles and first ever night run. Ellie guided him around in a time of 48 minutes. A really good time, better than Daddy's 50 minute night lap.

Lap 1 Lap 2

After showers, a chance to sleep at 1am. Unfortunately Joey tried to clean his knee with water in the tent above Daddy's sleeping bag. Needless to say Daddy had an uncomfortable, damp sleep. Uncomfortable because the knee was hurting bad.

Daddy Completing Lap 1

Night runner

Daddy managed to get Jessica and Mummy £25 Thorpe Park annual passes off Eagle Radio. So along with Ben and Alice Teale they headed to the Theme Park and enjoyed themselves for the day. Ben went around with his mates.

Meanwhile Katie was with the Teales and visited Brighton.... again! She was spoilt and was taken on the fair rides and shopped in the Lanes.

title.value: Teale Swap - Thorpe Park and Brighton

info.content:
We went out with the Burrows and Elders to Liquid Leisure which is a big water adventure park in Wraysbury.

Later Alice came over to us for a sleepover with Jessica, whilst Katie headed in the other direction and stayed with Summer overnight.

title.value: Water Inflatables with Burrows and Elders. Alice, Katie swap sleepover

info.content:
Written by Farfar

It was an early start on the Wednesday, but not as much as the outward journey, for our journey back to England. Graham and Susan took Jette to Thyregod railway station as she was going to Copenhagen to stay with Joan and Gert for their joint 70 birthday celebrations. The rest of us went direct, well via some country roads actually, to the airport for the 11.15 flight back to Blighty. It was delayed here and there which eventually put an extra hour on the clock but we all got home under a leaden sky mid afternoon, happy but exhausted. It had been quite an intense holiday, even if we were unable to experience the delights of Rørbæk Sø!

Written by Farfar

It was wall to wall sun again on the Tuesday. Having run out of theme parks for the time being, we all went to Horsens, and the newly opened museum that once was a Victorian prison. It proved to be bigger and more comprehensive than first imagined. Katie was absolutely fascinated with the place. She has a thing for prisons at the moment.

Katie in Horsens Prison

Farmor's Uncle who worked at the prison

Tempting to drop her off

Later, we journeyed into the town and took in the shops. Ben and Martin though, hired a couple of ‘Boris Bikes’ at the prison and made their own way into town, but we met up for a while near the main square.

Route

Daddy and Ben Bike ride around Horsens

The next item on our itinerary was to swim in a lake. Jette had done this in Ejstrupholm So as a child but a repeat performance was not possible as there were too many reeds separating bank and water. We took a fifteen minute drive over to Hampen Sø which was suitable and the Frimley Green contingent took a dip, although Laura was uncertain about the experience after seeing fish swimming about. The lake was something akin to Frensham Pond but without the crowds.

Hampen Lake for a Mermaids outing

We stopped off at Ejstrupholm church and the Uhrskov stone for some photo oppotunities and see if we could spot any ancestors in the graveyard. There were some Uhrskovs and Hansens, but none rang a bell in the current family tree.

We then returned back to the house for a short while before rolling off again, almost back to the same place, but this time a little nearer, to the roadside café for a full evening meal.

Ejstrupholm church

The Uhrskov Stone - don't look at the spelling!

When we went back to the house, a car was there when we arrived with Johanas sat in it. I did say that we would visit him during the day on the Tuesday but the Horsens trip, planned at short notice, thwarted that idea. Anyway, he suggested we might like to go to the airfield (that he formally owned) for a drink at its clubhouse. Thus, me Jette and Martin did for an hour and met half a dozen other people to watch the sun set over the heather in amiable conversation. It turned out one couple had stayed in Deepcut when the Farnborough air show was on a little while back. The place again threw up move coincidences.

Meeting Johanas

title.value: Denmark Day 4 - Horsens Prison, Bike Ride, Hampen Lake Swim, Airstrip Johanas

info.content:
Written by Farfar

Monday morning broke with yet more sunshine. This time the journey was not so far as we went back to Billund, this time to Legoland. We set out a little later than planned and arrived soon after opening time. All nine of us stayed until the six o’clock closing time and ran out of minutes to fit all the rides as they stopped at five. The place was quite busy but with hardly any queues for the rides. Not all the adults went on with the kids, but most were represented by one or other of the older generation.

The highlights were the aquarium where we saw a shark close up as well as manta rays. We even got to get tickled by a shrimp! The Lego cars were eagerly awaited and didn't disappoint. Katie was an expert at pulling off a u'ie without notice, Ben an expert at looking cool and easy and Jessica loved a good car wash and petrol station visit. There was the River Tyre ride which Daddy got soaked on (see video) and possibly the most exhilarating rides were at the end of the day. Mummy said the Polar Express rollercoaster ride was the best she's been on, whilst Ben absolutely loved the Ice Pilots School where you could design your own ride. Sounds a bit bonkers. Anyway overall a good visit.

Legoland - Billund

Katie swimming in the aquarium

Jessica stuck in the aquarium

Tickled by the shrimp

Lego Millennium Falcon

Beautiful smile

Trouble on the roads. Evacuate!

Legal to drive now

Log Flume ride

Fars join us for the rapid river drop

Billund Airport

The evening was spent back at base playing board games or watching the television which was dominated by football. Jette and I went for a walk around Ejustrupholm which, as expected, was pretty well deserted. However, I was pleased with myself after conducting a ten minute conversation alone, entirely in Danish with a local man who was walking his dog. Martin came too and, in the meanwhile, tested out his knee with a 5K run around the village.

Route

Written by Farfar

Sunday morning dawned full of sun. An isolated rain storm was forecast but none were encountered at any time. This time we set off for the Summerland Theme Park near Randers. The journey, at a little over two hours. Rather than run along the motorway for most of the miles, I wanted to take a more picturesque route via Silkeborg, but one route was closed so we had to divert along country lanes and there was more holiday traffic on the roads than expected. We got there a little before noon.

They were delighted to see the queue times were very low. There was the usual fill of rollercoaster rides, however it was the other bits and pieces that made this different. The family quad cycles, the 50 or so trampolines, the air cushion, the basketball, the canoeing around a lake. They were there right to the end at 6pm.

High risers

Drive by

Log flumes

Canoeing

Written by Farfar.

This was a gathering of the clan in that Martin, Laura, Susan, Graham, Katie, Jessica and Ben joined me and Jette for a four night foray into deepest Denmark; to Ejstrupholm to be precise. We all traveled together on the 7.45am flight from T5 at Heathrow to Billund which meant a really early start from our respective homes, but we all made it on time. The day was bright and flight smooth, if a little noisy as it appeared to be doubling up as the ‘Legoland Special.’ We touched down on time at around 10.30 (Danish time) then spent an eternity queuing to go through passport control. There were only two positions available which was obviously inadequate.

That hurdle passed, our next task was to collect our vehicles. Susan and Graham had their own Merc but the rest of us had to do with a more functional nine seater ‘bus,’ but one that did the job admirably well throughout our stay that stretched over four nights. We set off into the sunshine to the nearby town Grinsted and arrived to a near deserted town centre soon after noon to seek a cafe for lunch. A walk through the main street, popping into what shops were open (most close at one o’clock on a Saturday in Denmark), brought us to a highly suitable eatery where we sat outside in the sunshine for a varied lunch.

Katie and the church in Grinsted

Thus sated, our next task was to stock up with provisions which we managed at the Kvickly supermarket (in contrast, they stay open all hours) in the town of Brande, five miles from our destination. Beer, of course, was an important item in the inventory, along with sufficient food to get us through the weekend. Arrival at our destination was effected by about two thirty which gave us an hour to settle in before our first event.

The accommodation was at the Damgard B and B on Fasterholt Vej, set back 200 yards or so, just outside Ejustrupholm. It was an annex of a former farm and set in many acres of land that could be explored. Downstairs, it consisted of a utility room, kitchen, living room, one bedroom and a bathroom, all of generous size and well appointed. Upstairs lay a large landing, a room in itself, a bathroom, two ‘normal’ bedrooms and a large family bedroom. There was heaps of room all round.

Our first adventure, the Lego House, beckoned for we had tickets for a 4.00pm entry. Billund, direct, took a smidgen over half hour. Our time at Lego House was the full four hours and proved to be very entertaining for all of us. Favourites were the Stock photo filming, car racing and fish designing as well as marveling at all the Lego villages, dinosaurs, trees, etc.

Making a Lego stock movie

Lego Dinosaurs

Tonight was the Mytchett Athletic FC Presentation evening. Daddy presented the boys with trophies. Abe won the Player's Player and Supporters Player of the year awards. Charlie got Manager's Player. Daddy got a load of beers and a trophy.

Jessica was picked for the school cricket team who played in a Surrey Heath schools tournament over at the Marconi recreation ground. Jessica's team came second out of six and enjoyed it enough to continue play cricket at school.

Jessica chasing the runs

We split up as a family today. First off was mummy who had to go to some church meeting in Windlesham, Daddy rode his bike on a 12 mile Blackwater River ramble which took in the parkrun at Rushmoor - he supported his fellow Frimley Flyers.

Ma Ma, Pop Pop and Grandma all came over for a Royal Wedding BBQ.

Farfar got FA Cup tickets through Chertsey Town FC. There was some debate whether Daddy or Farfar was going to accompany Ben into the ground. All three traveled to the greasy spoon in Hillingdon before moving onto the stadium. There was aobut 90,000 spectators. Farfar took Ben into the Man Utd end. Daddy watched the game outside and enjoyed sitting against the stadium listening to the radio commentary. He had a luck escape as the game itself was very drab and disappointing. Chelsea beat Man Utd 1-0.

In Wembley Stadium

Flying the red flag in vain

Jessica went swimming with Ma Ma in the afternoon.

In the evening Mummy and Katie went to the Maisey's for a Murder Mystery party.

Mysterious murderers

title.value: FA Cup Final, Royal Wedding, Maisey Murder Mystery, Swimming

info.content:
Jessica and Mummy, joined Natasha and Lily for the mermaids second outing at the Keys. They had good fun.

Daddy went off to do his coaching course again at Winston Churchill school. The third of six sessions done. More of the same. Planning and carrying out coaching sessions.

The rest of us went to the cinema in the afternoon.

Mermaids

title.value: More Mermaids, FA Coaching course, cinema

info.content:
In the morning Daddy who is injured, volunteered at parkrun. It was hard for him not to run. Farfar however, did run!

Farfar running!

Katie and Ben went with Catherine and Johnny down to Brighton to stay in the family static caravan for the night. They shopped and bought quite a few items of clothes. They also had some nice food in subwway and KFC. The weather wasn't great so they didn't make much use of the beach.

Katie, Ben, Johnny and Catherine playing in Brighton

In the evening Jessica decided she was going to do Bake Off, but got confused with Come Dine With Me. Earlier in the afternoon she went out with Mummy to get all the ingredients she needed for her 3 course meal. She was so sweet as she wanted to keep it a secret and do all the cooking herself..... she even made a colourful menu up. For starters she made soup, mains was home made potato chips, chicken breast, sweetcorn and cucumber. Pudding was Eton mess. Very well executed. We even got a glass of hot chocolate!

Jessica cooked dinner

Jessica and Mummy slept in the tent for a second night.... although at about 3am they came inside as they got scared and decided to punish Daddy by drawing makeup on his face. Daddy had the last laugh though, as he woke secretly and ROARed at them when they least expected it. It didn't do much for Mummy's anxiety!

title.value: Katie and Ben Over nighter in Brighton, Jess cooking and back garden camper

info.content:
In the evening Mummy and Jessica setup the tent in the back garden and slept all night in there.

Daddy headed down to the Prince Of Wales in North Farnborough and met up with Nick, Phil, Martin and Barrie. Nick announced he was getting married at the end of the month.

Nick looking on as Barrie opens Christmas and Birthday cards

Hopefully, the traditionally participation of the Windle Valley Pairs 10km event which we entered two teams into. Team 1 the seniors, Mummy and Daddy. Team 2 the juniors, Ben and Katie. There was some competition as Daddy and Ben were roughly equal and the girls were largely an unknown quantity. The girls set off first from Windlesham Memorial field and headed off down towards the playground. The race was a relay with 1km intervals. Each person did 5x1km. Sounds easy, but in fact very hard, as you are killing yourself 5 times.

Katie came around the first lap before mummy which condemned the old'uns to a loss. However, everyone did very well. Daddy unfortunately picked up an injury which really only became apparent the day after when he could barely walk. It was the cartilage in his left knee again! Well done fam. You did amazing. Same again next year.

Katie handing over to Ben

The Gallivanting Gays

Another boiling hot day and another early departure from chez Gay, this time heading north to Warwick Castle.

We arrived and had a long walk from the carpark to the main entrance. The castle looked impressive. There was plenty to do. We saw the old fashioned cannon / catapult in action which was interesting. We also had a small guided tour looking at the owners and how scathing they were. We then walked around the ramparts and towers in the castle, saw the gaol, the time tunnel and watched the archery. Inter-family rivalry was rife in the maze. Claim and counter claim who the real winner was, was debated hard! We were exhausted from all the walking around in the heat and the ups and downs.

The gang one of the regal rooms

Katie with her armour

The gang again infront of the main castle quatres

In the keep

Send them to the tower

From up high

We made our way down to visit the Elders for Michael's 40th birthday BBQ. Ma Ma and Pop Pop were also there. Lovely BBQ punctured by Henry being sick multiple times. We got Michael a track day experience driving 3 super cars around his favourite circuit, Brands Hatch. A nice time had by all. A fitting end to an exhausting bank holiday weekend.

Jessica waterfall

Early doors and Mummy and Jessica went off for their open water swim at Mytchett.

In the afternoon Ben and Mummy went to the cinema to watch Infinity Wars.

Daddy started his FA football coaching course. It was an all day event. There must have been 15 or so students at Winston Churchill school in Knaphill. It was another boiling hot day and half of the tutoring was done outside - this gave Daddy a bit of a tan!

Meanwhile the rest of us went to church and church club

title.value: Mermaids, FA Coaching Course, Inifinity Wars

info.content:
We had a busy day. There was just four of us waking up in the house. Katie was away in the east part of Surrey doing her Duke Of Edinburgh award hike.

We headed up to London, starting at Gunnersbury and the parkrun. Ben and Daddy were going to take it easy, but when do we ever believe that. There is only one gear, and that's full throttle. They were pleased with their sub 25 minute performance. Meanwhile Jessica and Mummy played hide and seek around the playground area. Route

They moved on in the sweltering heat to the underground station and headed to Southwark. A short walk near the Shard and onto the Clink. London's private jail it seemed for the area owned by the Bishop of Winchester. It sounded like the owners were as crocked as the inmates. There were many tales of torture. Jessica and Ben were pleasantly surprised with it. It must have consumed 90 minutes of our time. Next up lunch and a tour around the nearby Borough market. Ben and Mummy got a scrummy pie and Daddy some expensive bread. They were selling doughnuts, 4 for £10! Somewhere to come back to one day. We sat and ate by the Golden Hind.

The Shard

In the chair

Inprisoned

We then strolled long the south side of the Thames towards Embankment. We marvelled at some of the street entertainers. Ben stood next to man who was sitting on thin air!

Route

How's he sitting down?

We made it back to the car and drove to Banstead Woods to collect Katie. We were not too sure when she'd arrive. We waited a good couple of hours. She had got lost earlier in the day, so was one of the last groups back. She done ever so well, carrying more than most. She has a real determination. It sounded that she had barely eaten so quite concerned. She could chose whatever she wanted for dinner. Fish and Chips was on the menu. Well done Katie.

Katie finished DofE

title.value: Gunnersbury parkrun, The Clink, Bankside walk, Katie D of E

info.content: A huge write off - that car that we bought last summer. Having pursued the car firm through the small claims courts and won, we decided not to press on with the bailiffs option as there was so much paper work, more costs and after speaking with Dave Rayner little chance of getting our money back. It has been a huge headache and we've decided to cut our losses. Recently got the car MOT'ed at a cost of £250. Sold it for £2,800 and after all the other costs, we must be over £2500 down in total. Grrrr

We all slept well last night. We waited till 8:30 before breakfast was served. It was worth the wait as well. £65 for the 5 of us including a good breakfast. Great value. We set off after 10 having first fixed a puncture on Katie's bike.

We headed south towards Christ's Hospital, Southwater and West Grinstead still along the railway line which ceased being as a result of the Beeching Report in 1966. It was colder than yesterday and people's bottoms were sore! We made good progress and stopped at a supermarker in Henfield for lunch. Jessica was doing ever so well, much better than yesterday. She was happy as she stuffed the iPad in the rucksack, set some tunes up and pressed play.

Jessica pushing it up the hill

We finally reached the end of the Downs Link path at the mouth of the River Adur in Shoreham. Next we headed west along the coast towards our final destination Brighton. It was tough going against the wind. Jessica was now going super slow..... but she stuck at it. We went on the spit of land along Basic Road South. Not much traffic and some big industrial units shipping ballast, steel and wood by the looks of things. We got to the promenade at Portslade and travelled to Hove admiring the views. We saw the burnt out pier and the new tower hanging over Brighton. We eventually arrived at the Palace Pier in the mid afternoon pretty well spent and ready for our treat, McDonalds!

Finished the Downs Link part at Shoreham

Reached Brighton Pier

We meandered our way through the Lanes and up to the main street to get our Makkie D's. We then had a small climb to reach the railway station. Two Adult tickets and 3 children tickets were £115. However, 3 adults and 2 child tickets were £86! Got to love the web of train ticketing. The galling thing was, no one checked our ticket all the way home!

We had a small problem when we reached Shalford. There was engineering works all the way to North Camp. Therefore we had to negotiate our bikes onto the coach.... which fortunately Daddy did somehow. The railway employee said it was not allowed. To finish our trip we had the short ride from North Camp to home. In total we did 55km and 61km = 116km over the weekend. Well done Gay's. Route

This is year 2 of spending a long time on a bike ride as a family. This year we aimed to get to Brighton starting from home. All five bikes were prepared. Daddy, Ben and Jessica all had upgrades from last year, and we bought our own paniers this time.

The weather forecast was a little dodgy. Fortunately the rain didn't come, although it was pretty cold. We put Ben in charge of navigation. He had the phone with the map and route on it. Well we didn't have a great start, Mummy forgot her inhaler, so turned back, then Ben started leading us the wrong way. We hadn't even got out of Frimley Green!

We got to Ash Ranges and the red flags were up, so we had to detour around into Pirbright. After a couple of hours we hit Guildford and sought refuge in Starbucks with a much needed warm drink and treats. Then it seemed a constant uphill struggle all the way up to St Martha's Church where there was a wedding and lots of DoE children. We stopped for lunch here overlooking the countryside.

Church At Pirbright

At St Martha's

Then the toughest parts of the journey hit us. It was extremely muddy through the Surrey Hills down through Bramley. Despondency was rife through the ranks as well as wet, muddy feet. We literally ploughed on and eventually got past the worst of it as we got to the disused railway line at Bramley. Daddy took up the wrong path which led us to some technically challenging terrain.

Finally we got on to the disused train line for some considerable time. We went along some straight track all the way to Cranleigh where we stopped for refreshments, before pushing on to our half way point of Slinford where we rested for the night. The Red Lyon was situated in the middle of the picturesque village. We had a room with just 4 single beds, so Mummy and Jessica cuddled up together. We didn't find it hard to get to sleep once we had our Dominoes pizza.

Finished for the day at the back of the Red Lyon

Route

title.value: Downs Link 1: Biking Home to Slinford

info.content:
The Fars had hired the hall out the back of the Surrey Cricketers, Windlesham for a mini birthday party for Farmor who celebrated 70 years - well yesterday anyway.

The Rostocks and both Auntie Susan's in laws and Ma Ma and Pop Pop were also in attendance. We arrived an hour early to dress the room up to make it all nice for Farmor. We sat and drank and ate a very nice meal. Susan had bought a selfie polaroid photo thing, which we had fun with. We also had a game of skittles which Ben was obviously the most competitive about. He managed to put off Ma Ma on one of her attempts, but Ma Ma had the last laugh as she made Ben miss completely! Of course Ben wiggled his way out by reminding us of the aggregate score!

Ben was on DJ duty and Katie on photos. Farmor opened her presents and Farfar made a funny speech. I don't think it was intentionally funny! We all had a nice time.

Top Table

Farmor and Joan

Birthday girl with the Denmark birthday cake

The three of us

Muma and a Dadda

Farmor's school friend, Joan and her husband Gert came over to England to visit. We invited them over for some tea and cakes so we could catch up. It was very nice to see they were fit, healthy and the same as ever.

The Rostocks

The inauguration swim of the Frimley Flippers took place this morning at the Kingfisher, Mytchett. Mummy and Jessica went off at 8am in their wet suits for a swim. They said it was cold at first, but ok after that.

Meanwhile Daddy went off on a mountain bike ride into Ash Ranges and got a little lost. He refuses to turn back, so when the path got narrower and narrower he forged ahead dragging the bike through the swampy bits of the Ranges. We're convinced no one else has done that route on a bike before.

Ash Ranges

Route

Daddy did a BBQ Sunday lunch which was nice, especially as we sat outside in the sun. We then biked in the woods to the Mytchett Canal centre. We hired a pedalo and proceeded to be a menace on the water ways. Ben got grumpy and frustrated that he couldn't steer the vessel. Anyway it was fun. We had an ice cream after and went home to watch some more Prison Break.

Pedalo'ing

First up was parkrun and the Flyers were doing a pacing weekend. We had representatives from 20 to 40 mins and at some points we had two of us running. Daddy paced 27 minutes with Alfie. It was so nice to help people along.

Flyers Pacers

We had our penultimate fixture of the season at Heatherside. We had a full squad of all 15 players which was nice to see. We could get a squad lineup photo. We ran out winners by 5-1. Things are a little more calm this week. Ben had to leave at half time to go to his next event.

Mytchett Athletic Falcons U13s 2017/18. Top: Loz, Oli, Tom, Abe, Cam, Ben H, Jayden, Charlie, Daddy. Bottom: Callum, Kieran, Yuv, Freddie, Ethan, Alex, Dan, Ben G

The next event being quad biking down at the edge of the New Forest. Ben and Joey had an hour and a half of circling a track. The confidence grew and grew. Joey had a moment where he lost concentration and hit the barriers quite hard which shook him up for a bit. He continued on. Ben came off absolutely loving it. He was full of it. We like to see that.

Quad biking

Ben headed off to the Elders to stay the night. The rest of us went home and watched Die Hard. Too much swearing in it!

title.value: Parkrun Pacing, Football, Quad Biking, Ben Sleepover

info.content: Ben had an outstanding Parent's evening and interim school report, whilst Katie was rewarded the Titanium award for attaining lots of award points. Jessica achieved Star of the Week at school for being kind to her friends.
Mummy, Daddy, Ben and Jessica went to the rec to play cricket for 30 minutes in the evening. Very nice.

Daddy went off to Alton to meet with some friends to do a 40 miler. Route

In the afternoon Daddy and Ben went to Aldershot Banger racing along with the Elders and Ma Ma and Pop Pop. Daddy chatted with Gary there which was funny. The highlight was undoubtedly the American Styled DD at the end. All the cars were in a squared off part of the track. They faced each other and when the flag went down some just drove full speed into their opposite number. Mental.

Aldershot Krew in the rain

title.value: Alton Bike Ride and Aldershot Bangers

info.content: Parkrunned at Frimley as we had a match straight after against Yateley Pumas.

Daddy's glucose control isn't too good and he's taken it upon himself to improve his situation. To that end he's bought the Libre Freestyle sensors which is stuck in your arm and uses NFC comms with the phone to download the results. A pretty graph is drawn using the XDrip+ app. Time will tell if things improve.

Daddy did his usual DIY Passport photos

Passport

In the morning we went with the Turners over to the Crowthorne section of Swinley Forest for a MTB run. Ben having been ill recently didn't have much in the legs. It was nice to do some parts of Swinley not previously tackled before. It was pretty muddy out there. Route

Ben suffering in Swinley

In the afternoon we went over to Ma Ma and Pop Pops for a belated family Easter party. It was pretty manic with all the children there playing various party games.

Ma Ma's party

title.value: Swinley MTB, Ma Ma's Easter Family Party

info.content:
Ben not feeling too well and no football, Daddy saw this as an opportunity to do another tourist parkrun. It was at Hazelwood, where London Irish train.

We headed off to do walk 100 over in Pangbourne. We thought it was walk 99 at the time, so no big celebration! It was a wet, wet day. Daddy and Ben only wore trainers and subsequently ended up with wet feet as they walked along the Thames. Katie and Jess played in one of the streams. On our way home we popped in to Steven's for a catch-up and a cup of tea. When we got home Daddy and Ben were happy to watch the Manchester derby. Route

River Thames, Pangbourne

title.value: Hazelwood parkrun, Walk 100 - Pangbourne, Steve Tea

info.content: Daddy had a two day training course in posh offices in Paddington. It was on becoming a Certified Scrum Master. The course was very interesting. Daddy passed the exam so he is now certified!

Ben really wasn't feeling too good, so stayed at Ma Ma and Pop Pop's whilst the rest of us headed down to Lymington to catch the ferry over to the Island Of Wight as Jessica terms it. We were foot passengers and enjoyed the 45 minute journey across the murky Solent, playing Uno. Once arrived we caught the bus, where the driver was experiencing her first ever drive in her new job!

We reached base camp at the Needles. It was a series of shops and entertainments, like a mini holiday area. It was deserted, we guess due to the poor weather. We watched a 4D cinema film, then went on the scary chair lifts down the cliff to the water's edge. It was windy and rainy. Katie was pretty scared. The chairs do ascend/descend across a fairly steep gradient.

The chair ride down

We caught the tourist bus up to the Needles, but didn't explore around as the weather was appalling. We ended back at Yarmouth to grab lunch from the bakery. Skimmed stones on the mini beach before catching an early boat back to the main land again.

Needles in the background. Somewhere

Making sand bottles

Katie expressed a desire to go and see the shops owned by TOWIE stars (The Only Way Is Essex). We jumped at the chance, so headed around the M25 to Brentwood. We trawled the High Street and visited half a dozen shops and some of the hang out haunts used in the program. Katie was very self conscious of not looking sad when taking photos of her in front of these shops. One of the last we visited we actually went in and Katie bought some clothes.

Outside Chloes, Brentwood High Street

Daddy decided that he was going to bike home and so got on his road bike and headed off towards London. He passed the Olympic Stadium, Bank, London Wall and the Houses Of Parliament. It took him 6 hours to get home!

Route

London Wall

Olympic Swimming Centre

title.value: Brentwood Towie Shopping - Cycle Home Through London

info.content:
Jessica still not feeling too well today. However, after some medicine she lasts for a couple of hours in the land of living. We had a decorate your egg and handing over chocolate eggs to each other. Daddy didn't get mummy an egg this year, citing that there are too many in the house.

Eggselent Breakfast

Daddy stayed behind to garden and look after Jessica whilst the rest of us went to church. Ben confidently made a reading in front of the congregation. People remarked how well he did. That boy does not suffer from nerves.

We had Susan and Graham and the Fars over for Sunday lunch. Mummy had slow boiled beef in a gravy. It was very nice. Jessica and Ben made pudding which consisted of taking the top off an Easter egg and filling it with chocolate ice cream, raspberries, blueberries and cream. Not one for the health enthusiasts. Charlotte, Loz and Lenny later popped by as well.

Easter lunch

title.value: Ben church reading, Easter Sunday with Gay's

info.content:
Daddy on a bit of a mission of not repeating runs or bike ride routes at the moment. Therefore he decided to try a new parkrun, Osterley Park. Half of it was on proper paths the other half on grass and with all the rain it became a bit of a mud bath.

Route

After rushing home we all then went out to Reading town centre and met with the Sanders to go in the Compassion HGV lorry. There were separate rooms recreating the life of a Ugandan girl. Her home, school, hospital. It was there so you could potentially sponsor a child. It had little impact on the children I think, but we thought it important to go, to attempt to show how lucky the children should feel.

Outside The Compassion Centre

After a photo and a face painting we headed off to Pinkney's Green and a National Trust egg hunt. We got there just in time as we hadn't noticed the 2pm closing time. It was a little disappointing as there were no clues to solve and turned out to be a 1km circular walk around a field! We collected our eggs and swapped Easter goodies between the families.

Pinkney's Green Egg Hunt

Route

After we scooted to Camberley as we had to get our eyes tested. Jessica had her done at the hospital and they were fine. Both Ben and Katie didn't need glasses, although Katie really wanted them so she could look intelligent, so she says.

Mummy and Daddy both needed reading glasses. Mummy embarrassed us all with her selection. Katie almost ran out of the shop in distress! Daddy couldn't find a pair that he and mummy liked.

title.value: Osterley Park parkrun, Compassion Bus, Pinkney's Egg Hunt, Eye Test

info.content:
In the morning the Elders came over and joined us for the Easter workshop at St Andrews church. Ben ran the obstacle course game for the children. The children love him. There were arts, crafts and food making stalls. After there was a church service that even Daddy stayed for. The Elders popped back for a cuppa before parting ways. We went over to Sylvies for the annual egg hunt at her house.

Ben running the Children's obstacle course

After watching a couple of episodes of Prison Break Season 1, Daddy left us to motorbike to Reading. It was raining lots. Phil had a ticket for him which was most generous. It was a good game to watch with Reading 1-0 for most of it, despite going down to ten men and conceding a penalty in the 90th minute. The QPR fans weren't happy when it was saved. There were some coins being thrown between the fans.

title.value: Good Friday Workshop, Sylvie's Egg Hunt, Reading v QPR

info.content:
In the morning Ben went off to Thorpe Park with his friends: Oli, Kieran and Yuv. First of many this year it sounds. They went on all the big rides. They experienced the Derren Brown ghost train simulator ride for the first time.

Thorpe Parkers

Daddy meanwhile has got a thing for filling in his running and biking heatmaps. Today there was a large hole in the Wokingham area so headed without a plan to that area. He found it tough going. After lunch we watch some more Prison Break season 1 which we like at the moment.

Mummy and Jessica went to church, whilst Katie was still recovering from her DoE exploits. In the afternoon Daddy went off to New Malden to pickup Jessica's new bike and collect the boys.

title.value: Ben Thrope Park, Daddy Wokingham Ride, Katie Party

info.content:
Katie Gay spent last night out in a two man tent with Georgia somewhere in the Surrey Hills.She had to walk 9 miles with a massive rucksack on her back and today she walked 15 miles. The tent she had unfortunately was a beach tent apparently, so was not waterproof. Of course it rained, so poor old Katie only managed to get to sleep at 4am!

Today she walked from Puttenham down to Farley Green, then back up to Newlands Corner. They got lost a bit, so re-traced their steps to get on the right track. Out of the 5 who started in their group, only 3 finished!

Meanwhile Ben had a game, without Daddy being there, against Cove Leopards who they beat 8-1 two weeks ago. Unfortunately we lost 1-0 to a dodgy penalty. Cove had some players back and looked a different team. The spirits were good, although we are having difficulties with the players commitment and one of the parents who thinks they know best.

Daddy was equally active in the morning. He motorbiked down to Salisbury and did their 4 lap parkrun. It was OK, not his favourite circuit. He then continued down to join the other Frimley Flyers for their Rio arranged brewery tour. Rio are owned by Hall and Woodhouse who brew Badger beer in Blandford Forum. So he spent a couple of hours on the tour as well as sampling a couple of the beers.

Hall and Woodhouse Flyers

After picking up Katie in the afternoon we had a nice treat Fish and Chip dinner and collapsed in front of the TV. Katie was asleep by 8:30pm!

title.value: Duke Of Edinburgh, Football, Salisbury parkrun, Hall and Woodhouse Brewery tour

info.content: We went to see Jessica's teacher for parents' evening. She had been doing badly in Maths and English.... Here results were below 10% in tests. The teacher did not understand why this should be so in Maths. She had been doing well. Jessica said she felt under time pressure in the tests. In English she is not great at spelling... and for the last test she hadn't realized there was more than one page of questions! Anyway we have arranged Jessica to have some tutoring with Ma Ma, once a week starting in the Easter holidays to try and get her back up to the mainstream. We are not too worried (worried nonetheless) as we don't think she's as bad as the results say.

It was supposed to be a packed day today. However, because of the snow, the Fleet Half Marathon which Daddy was supposed to run and our afternoon over in Gillingham with Helen and Fiona had been cancelled. This meant we had a lazy day at home doing odd jobs, church and a marathon game of Trivial Pursuit which Ben eventually won. We all were within one cheese of winning.

In the evening Daddy went with Jessica and Ben onto the hill at the rec. They were the only ones there to go sledging. Brilliant.

We started the day with snow threatening us. It was bitterly cold outside. Daddy started off with a trip to Frimley Lodge and parkrun. He took it particularly easy because of the impending Fleet Half marathon the day after..... which in fact later got called off!

parkrun

The Falcons had an important game against Liss Cobras Blue. The losers were pretty certain not to get the remaining promotion spot.... and unfortunately we lost 5-2. It was possibly the coldest game ever, with snow being brushed off so we could see the lines. We had 4 subs as well which meant we had to rotate constantly otherwise they would have frozen to the ground! A mixture of weather, lack of effort and poor attitude probably led us to defeat having been in the lead at 2-1.

Falcons in the snow

In the afternoon Daddy and Ben headed off to Cobham services. Daddy had bought a Bike Box from a person living in Ashford. He had hoped it was Ashford, Middlesex. But no it was of course Ashford, Kent! Luckily the man was travelling to Wimbledon which was lucky as we were going that way too. The chap even reduced the price of the bike box to £80. Bargain. Once collected the boys headed up to the Imperial War Museum as Ben had been pretty enthusiastic about wars (is that a good thing?). They parked around the corner at about 4:15pm so had just under 2 hours to explore the place.

They started at the bottom of the museum intending to make their way up. Ben was so interested they spent most of the time in the World War I section. It was very well laid out. The exhibits were interesting. Ben tried to justify his hours spent on the PlayStation by identifying all the guns. Again a bit of a worry. The boys vowed to return back in the summer after a London parkrun.

Imperial War Museum

After, they headed down the cosmopolitan Walworth Road and a KFC beckoned. Ben's choice. And it was greasy. A bargain bucket with 6 chicken pieces. Daddy was almost sick after that. Ben couldn't munch his way through all that!

About to enter the Academy a la Brixton

Next stop was Brixton. They parked 5 minutes away from the O2 Academy and met with the Harvey's in the seating at the top. It was Ben's first proper gig. He thought it was very loud but was rocking away, especially to Buck Rogers! The boys had a great day.

It finished at 11pm. There was driving snow. They gave the Harvey's a lift home. Didn't get home until quatre to one.

title.value: parkrun, Ben Football, Imperial War Museum, Feeder Gig, Lily sleepover

info.content:
After watching Evie's show last weekend, Jessica has become very enthusiastic to join in a play or production. So we joined her up with the group that Katie was with last year, and Katie's friend Catherine is still a member of.

Jessica came back after the two hour session having loved it. They played a mixture of games and she was introduced to the script, Romeo and Julliet. Jessica wondered who was going to play the role of the frog..... thinking it was Gnomeo and Julliet! She hadn't realized the Shakespearean aspect to the piece! She landed the role of one of the Capulet (Juliet's) family.

Mummy and Jessica went around to Ma Ma and Pop Pops to give Ma Ma her Mother's Day present. They snuck into the house and secretly made breakfast in bed for Ma Ma. Jessica pretended to be a burglar and shocked poor Ma Ma.

Daddy went to see Farmor. Mummy had presents from Jessica and Ben, but Katie lost her bank card so couldn't get anything!

Later in the afternoon we all went around to the Fars where we played games for an hour or so, before Katie and Ben went to Church Club.

Ben's card

Jessica's card

A busy morning. First Katie went along with Georgia to school as a prep meeting for her Duke Of Edinburgh bronze, hike and camp weekend. She took in her rucksack fully packed with tent, sleeping bag, the works. We bought her new boots, leggings, plate, tent, etc. for it.

Meanwhile the rest of us went to Cove Football Club to watch Ben play against Theo's team. Unfortunately Theo was not well, but the team played well and won the game 9-1! Ben had an average game.

We all met up for lunch back at home, then we headed towards Fareham, and Fort Nelson. We weren't sure what to quite expect. However, it was a grand fort with a museum and a chance to look at some guns, cannons, tunnels, and the fort itself. We must have been a couple of hours exploring around. Of course, Daddy and Ben paid more attention to the exhibits than the girls. We stopped off at Port Solent for a spot of Fish and Chips overlooking Porchester Castle on the way home.

Down in the tunnels in Fort Nelson

Eating Fish and Chips in Port Solent

In the evening Evie and Richard were performing in a show over in the Princes Theatre, Aldershot, so the girls went over to watch. the boys stayed in and watched 4 episodes of World War 2 In Colour!

title.value: 9-1 Football, Katie DoE prep, Fort Nelson, Evie show

info.content:
Daddy decided to run home from work today. Farfar gave him a lift in to work. There were many well wishers, especially with the weather being dark and dismal. Daddy didn't mind this. People at work were so sweet asking for a text when he got in, and to check his sugar levels. Sugar levels were at 14, so he took 4m/mols, to take the edge off. However, this was probably his downfall. After scaling the Hogs Back at Puttenham, Daddy began to feel a bit weary. Eventually after crossing the Ranges he called up mummy to collect him as he was struggling too much. His levels had dropped to 2.3! A challenge to re-try one feels.

Route

Jessica went in as Alice in Wonderland

Jessica in Wonderland

Daddy motorbiked up to London to visit the Museum of London which was very interesting. Interested to see the Romans building it up, then it went into nothing because the Romans left in 400ad. Then the like of the plague killed the population growth, and the boundaries were set for a long time - the London Wall. It wasn't until after the Great Fire London things accelerated again. It was quite interesting for Daddy.

Museum of London

Meanwhile the rest of us went over to Ma Ma and Pop Pop's.

title.value: Museum of London, Ma Ma and Pop Pops

info.content:
Ben slept over at Jonny's last night so we didn't see him in the morning.

The other 4 of us split in two. Daddy and Jessica went to do parkrun in the snow. Daddy pulled Jessica around the whole 3 mile course! Jessica enjoyed it!

Only 400 metres done

Canal turn

Flyers Lineup

Meanwhile Daddy gave Mummy a tri down the hairdressers.... and Mummy treated Katie to a trip as well. So they went to Grayderz in Frimley Green to have their hair chopped and eyebrows done.

At lunchtime Mummy and Daddy went for their annual Marie Curie collecting stint, this time at the Meadows.

Marie Curie collection

title.value: parkrun Sledge, girls hairdressers, Marie Curie collecting,

info.content:
It's been snowing on and off for the past 2 days. Today was the full day at home for us children as the schools were shut. Mummy and Daddy worked from home. We managed a number of trips up to the rec. There were loads of people there.

Jessie!

Jessica racing down Frimley Green rec

It was exceptionally cold all day. Daddy went for another training run, trailing the streets of Camberley attempting new roads so it'll look more diverse on a heat running map. Don't ask! Route

In the afternoon Ben went off to the cinema with Callum to watch Black Panther. The film got a thumbs up from him.

Daddy painted in the kitchen to freshen up some of the walls and did other DIY jobs. Mummy went to church and in the evening Ben and Katie went to a church session much to their dissatisfaction.

Painter

title.value: Long Run, Ben Cinema Black Panther

info.content:
Football was going to be at Frimley Lodge Park. However, Daddy was the one to decide whether it should be played or not. It was a tough decision and one that was made as he was on his second lap of parkrun!

This left a free spot in the afternoon. Just right for another walk. A longer one this time. 4.5 miles on Reigate Hill. We got lost a bit in the first mile and walked on some private farmers land and eventually crossed a foot bridge to a disused farm! Very spooky. Us children didn't moan as much as usual. We were primed early enough. Anyway we completed the muddy walk in a couple of hours and came home to some sweet treats from the shops and a nice mug of hot chocolate. Route

Reigate Hill temple

Reigate Hill walkers

In the evening Mummy and Daddy went out to Dave Peddle's 50th Birthday party held at Camberley Cricket Club. It was a fun evening as first there was some food, then a music quiz, which we clubbed together with Lee and the Erskines. After that there was a Russian Trio who entertained us with songs. Great fun. The Fars came to babysit us.

Party go-ers

title.value: parkrun, Walk 99 Reigate Hill, Dave Peddle 50th Party

info.content: Ben's starting to get really good friends with Johnny now. No.1 Friend? Ben, Johnny, Katie and Catherine went out to Camberley in the evening first to eat ice cream at Creams, then into the arcade to play some video games. All four returned for a sleepover at our house.

title.value: Ben and Katie Creams and Arcades with Catherine and Johnny + Sleepover

info.content:
In the morning Daddy and Ben went out mountain biking with Oli and Jon in the Tunnel Hill area. Route

Ben deep in a puddle

Mummy went to church, the rest of us lazy children stayed at home, objecting to keep Mummy company.

After a lovely Sunday lunch we headed off for a walk. Within a mile there was a problem with the brakes on the car, so we had to turn around and go back home. We flaked out in the afternoon and evening with a mix of card games, computer games and watching Winter Olympics.

We had an earlier than usual kick-off over on Ancells Park, Fleet. We were against Hart Tornados. They only had 10 men so we felt obliged to also only play with 10. We won the game 10-4.

After lunch we went over to Gravity Force to bounce up and down for an hour. After Daddy swapped his Valentines present for a couple of work shirts. We left him at the Meadows Roundabout as he wanted to run 11 miles home! Route

In the evening Mummy and Katie went to Prezzo in Camberley for a nice meal.

Pre School friends, Natasha, Nina and Grace

title.value: Falcons Football, 11 mile run, Gravity Force, Meal with Katie Preschool friends

info.content:
Daddy got mummy a haircut and a nice top, whilst mummy got daddy some trousers which were later swapped for a couple of smart work shirts from Next. They went to the Wheatsheaf in the evening for a meal.

Lovers

Daddy's card to mummy

In the morning Mummy ran Sunday school, whilst Daddy went out for a slow 10 mile run taking in Ash Ranges. Route

After Sunday lunch we went out for walk 98. Tidmarsh, outside Reading was the destination. A nice wildlife walk spoiled slightly by the roar of the M4! We started in the sunshine and Daddy even contemplated not taking a coat. Half way round we were hit by a couple of hail storms. It made things interesting!

Route

Monkies

Before hail storm

Football was again cancelled this week as the opposition could not field a team. Auntie Ellie and Mummy went off early to help Ma Ma and Pop Pop again at their car boot fair, whilst Daddy ran parkrun.

Later in the afternoon we picked up Ameret and Yuv and took them to Coral Reef. Steve and Matt had hired out the pool for an hour as a Christmas present. So there were 40 or 50 of us who had the pool and flumes all to ourselves. No one had been since they had done the place up. Other than the flumes it was difficult to see what they had done! The flumes were excellent. 3 requiring inflatable tyres and two quicker slides. We all had a great time.

Spa Pool

Volcano

Karen had arranged a birthday get together at a bar in Fleet which Mummy and Auntie Ellie were invited too. Lily came for a sleepover. Ellie was determined to cross off her getting drunk and go clubbing tick boxes as part of her to do list for turning 40. They had 6 cocktails.

Party girls

title.value: Mummy and Ellie going out out. Lily sleepover

info.content:
Daddy went out early door for a 40 mile bike ride with the Rockets.

Route

Rockets Riders

In the afternoon we all went down to the Harvester for lunch with the Home Bible group that Mummy sees each Wednesday.

At 6am we were awoken by Ma Ma and Pop Pop who were going to take Jessica and Katie to the car boot fair. They had a car boot-full of gear to sell. However, the girls were not very compliant. In the end mummy popped down to help out.

We had varied family support in the big match, Mytchett Falcons v Alton Huskies. It was a one sided affair to be honest. Joey playing in defence put in some solid tackles, whilst Ben in midfield played some nice passes. It ended with a home victory, 5-0. The Elders returned for some lunch before heading off in the afternoon to the Trampoline park in Basingstoke for Joey's 13th birthday party. They had an hours worth of fun before we all headed off to McD's for some nurishment! We parted ways with the Elders. Ben went to Alton for a sleepover, whilst Lily came home with us and played with Katie and Jessa. Ma Ma and Pop Pop also stayed the night.

Pre Bounce Shot

title.value: parkrun, boot fair, Falcons v Huskies, Joey 13th party, Sleepovers

info.content:
Jessica still not feeling too well so we didn't do too much more than play more Uno.

In the later afternoon, the Fars treated us to a couple of hours down the bowling alley. Daddy scored one of his best scores ever with 129. We of course had the guide rails up. It was good fun.

Uno

Ten Pin Bowling at Farnborough

Daddy parkrunned in the morning. The Falcons game was called off. It is very wet out there. Jessica was off school yesterday and wasn't feeling 100% today so we played some Uno.

In the evening Katie and Ben went on a sleepover to the same house (weird). Their friends Jonny and Catherine are siblings. They stayed up late and ate pizza.

title.value: parkrun, Falcons, Jonny and Catherine sleepover

info.content:
We got a message rom Eagle Radio to see if we wanted to par-take again the Family Faceoff game. Of course Mummy said yes. Jessica was her intended opponent, however Ben wanted to take a 2-0 lead. Here is a link to the video of the radio program!

Eagle Radio studio when we were on

Daddy and Ben woke to snow. As part of the Frimley Flyers league, Ben was running the Farnborough 5km with Daddy. As mummy was in Kent, the boys had to bike to the start by the airport. It was very cold. The boys arrived slightly late and missed the start. Fortunately times were recorded from a chip, so it didn't really matter too much. It did mean they started at the very back.
